I'd like to teach you a breathing technique that can help calm your nervous system, and we can practice it together right now. Also, I think it would be helpful to see you again before your presentation so we can build your confidence with these new tools. How does that sound?
Hello, Ms. Chen. Thank you for coming in today. I understand it might have taken considerable courage to seek help. What brings you here?
I... I have this absolutely terrifying fear of heights. It's getting worse, and it's really starting to affect my life.
Thank you for sharing that. It takes strength to acknowledge when a fear is impacting your life. Could you help me understand how this fear is affecting your daily activities?

I had to switch offices at work because my desk was near a window on the 15th floor. I can't take my kids to the amusement park anymore. Last week, I had a panic attack just trying to go up an escalator at the mall.

That sounds really challenging, especially since it's affecting both your work and family life. When you encounter these situations involving heights, what happens? Could you walk me through your experience?

My heart starts racing, I get dizzy, my palms get sweaty... Sometimes I feel like I can't breathe. I know it's irrational - the window at work had safety glass, the escalator is perfectly safe - but I just can't control it.

I want you to know that while these fears might feel irrational to you, your body's reactions are very real. These are genuine anxiety responses that can be incredibly overwhelming. Could you tell me how long you've been experiencing this level of fear?

I've always been nervous about heights, but it's gotten much worse in the past year. Now I'm starting to avoid more and more places. My daughter's school is having an event at the Science Museum next month, and I'm terrified because they have these open staircases...

It sounds like this fear has been progressively limiting your activities, which must be really frustrating. I notice you're planning ahead about potential challenges, like the Science Museum event. Could you tell me about other ways you've had to adapt your daily routine?

Yes, all the time. I take longer routes to avoid bridges, I won't go to any building higher than three stories, I always look for elevators instead of escalators. It's exhausting, and I feel like I'm letting my family down.

I hear the emotional toll this is taking on you, especially regarding your family. What you're describing aligns with what we call acrophobia, which is more than just a dislike of heights - it's an intense fear response that can significantly impact daily life. Would you like to understand more about what's happening when you experience these fears?
Yes, please. I just want to understand why I can't seem to handle what everyone else can.

It's important to understand that acrophobia isn't about being 'weak' or 'not handling' something. It's a specific type of anxiety disorder where your brain's fear response becomes overactive in relation to heights. Think of it like an oversensitive alarm system - it's trying to protect you, but it's responding too strongly. The good news is that we can work on recalibrating this response through various therapeutic approaches. One effective method is called exposure therapy. Would you like to know more about how that works?
Does that mean you'll make me go to high places right away? I don't think I can do that.

I understand your concern, and I want to assure you that exposure therapy never involves pushing you into frightening situations before you're ready. It's a gradual, step-by-step process where you're in control at all times. We might start with something very gentle, like looking at pictures of low heights from a comfortable distance, and only move forward when you feel completely ready. We can combine this with cognitive behavioral therapy to help you develop coping strategies and understand your thought patterns. How does that sound?
That sounds less scary. I really want to get better. My son graduates next year, and the ceremony is going to be in an auditorium with steep seating. I don't want to miss it.

Your son's graduation is a wonderful motivation, and it gives us a clear goal to work toward. While we develop our long-term treatment plan, I'd also like to teach you some immediate coping strategies that could help you feel more in control. These include specific breathing techniques and grounding exercises. Would you like to learn some of these tools today?

Hello Mrs. Thompson, and hello Emma. I'm so glad you both came to see me today. Emma, I have some colored pencils and paper here if you'd like to draw while we talk. Would you like to tell me a little bit about what's been happening?
It's about Emma. She's having a really hard time at school. The teachers called us because she's been crying every morning and refusing to stay in class.

Emma, it sounds like school has been feeling pretty tough lately. Could you help me understand how you feel when you're there? There's no right or wrong answer - I just want to learn more about what's happening.
I get scared something bad will happen to mommy while I'm gone. What if she gets sick and I'm not there? Or what if there's a fire at our house?
She's always been a bit clingy, but it's gotten much worse in the past two months. She won't even sleep in her own room anymore, and she gets physically sick with stomachaches before school.
That must be really hard for both of you. Emma, when you have these worried feelings about mommy, do they come at other times too? Like when you're not at school?
When mommy goes to the store... or when daddy travels for work. I get really scared they won't come back.
Thank you for telling me about that, Emma. It's really brave to talk about things that scare us. Mrs. Thompson, have you noticed any other changes in Emma's behavior or sleep patterns?
She's been having nightmares too. Almost every night she wakes up crying about something happening to us. We've tried everything - staying longer at drop-off, calling during lunch break...
It sounds like you've been working really hard to help Emma feel safe. Sometimes big changes or events in our lives can make worried feelings grow bigger. Has anything significant happened recently?
Well... Emma's grandmother - my mother - passed away three months ago. They were very close. That's when things really started getting worse.

I'm so sorry to hear about your mother, Mrs. Thompson. Emma, it must have been really hard to say goodbye to your grandmother. Sometimes when we lose someone we love, we start worrying more about other people we love too. Based on what you've both shared, Emma seems to be experiencing what we call separation anxiety disorder. Would you like me to explain what that means?
Yes, please. I want to understand what's happening and how we can help her.

Think of anxiety like an alarm system in our body that helps keep us safe. Sometimes, especially after we lose someone important to us, that alarm system becomes extra sensitive. Emma's mind is trying so hard to keep everyone safe that it's setting off worry alarms even when there isn't real danger. The good news is that we can help Emma's alarm system learn when it really needs to go off and when things are actually safe.
That makes sense... but what can we do? She can't keep missing school, and I hate seeing her so distressed.

Emma, would you like to be part of making a plan to help the worried feelings get smaller? We can work together to create some special tools just for you. One thing we can do is something called play therapy, where we use games and activities to help you feel braver about being away from mommy and daddy.
Will I have to stay away from mommy?

You know what, Emma? We'll only do things that you feel ready for. It's like learning to ride a bike - we start with training wheels and take them off only when you feel ready. We can even make it into a game where you earn special rewards for each brave step you take. Would you like to help choose the rewards?
Maybe... if mommy helps.
Should we be doing anything differently at home?

Yes, I'll help you create some special routines that can help Emma feel more secure. We can make a goodbye routine with a special hug or secret handshake, and maybe even create a comfort box with items that remind Emma of you when she's at school. We should also talk about ways to help Emma remember and honor her grandmother while learning that it's okay to feel happy and safe again.
And what about school? They're getting frustrated with the situation.

I understand their concern, and I'll work directly with the school to create a supportive plan. We can identify a special helper at school - maybe a favorite teacher or the school counselor - who can be Emma's safe person. Emma, would you like to help choose who that person might be? We can also set up a gradual return plan with some fun activities to make school feel more comfortable again. Mrs. Thompson, would you like to discuss some specific strategies we can start implementing this week?
Hello, Alison. I'm Dr. Taylor. Thank you for coming in today. I know taking this first step can be difficult. What would you like me to call you?
Alison is fine... My sister noticed I've been different lately. She told me I should come.
It sounds like your sister really cares about you. Could you tell me more about what's been happening? Take your time - we're here to understand this together.
Everything just seems to be piling up. I don't seem to be coping with things anymore... especially with the kids. It all feels very black.

That must be really overwhelming, especially while trying to care for your children. I'd like to understand better what you're experiencing. Would it be okay if I ask you some questions about how you've been feeling?
Yes.
Let's start with your energy levels. Many people find changes in their energy affect different parts of their life. How has this been for you?
I used to do a lot with the kids - swimming, playing. But now I just... I feel so exhausted. I've not been going to work as much. Even at the supermarket, they've noticed. Everything's just too much.
That sounds really difficult - going from being active with your children to feeling this exhausted. Sleep can often be connected to our energy levels. Could you tell me about your sleep patterns?
It takes me ages to fall asleep. I just lie there watching the clock. Then I wake up around 4 AM and can't get back to sleep. I used to read before bed, but now I can't even focus on that.
Those long nights must feel very isolating. I notice you mentioned not being able to focus on reading - have you noticed other changes in your daily routines, like your eating habits?
I used to have quite a good appetite, but the last couple of months... I've lost weight. The kids come home from school and make their own food now. I just can't be bothered.

It sounds like you're feeling guilty about the changes in how you care for your children. When we're struggling, even basic tasks can feel overwhelming. What about activities you used to enjoy? Have there been changes there too?
Nothing really. I used to go out with friends, take pictures... but now, what's the point? I'm just being useless at the moment.

I hear you being very hard on yourself, Alison. These changes you're describing aren't a reflection of who you are as a person or a mother - they're symptoms of something bigger that we can work on together. I need to ask you something important - have you had any thoughts about harming yourself?
A few years ago... I took some tablets. The kids were in bed, I'd had some wine... I just thought I'd go to sleep and not wake up. But I was sick everywhere.
Thank you for sharing that with me. I know it's not easy to talk about. What about now? Do you find yourself having similar thoughts?
Sometimes at night, when I'm watching the clock and I'm alone... everything feels so hard. But I'd never hurt my kids. They're what keeps me going.

I can hear how much you love your children, and how they give you strength even in difficult moments. Alison, what you're describing - the persistent low mood, sleep difficulties, loss of appetite and energy, trouble concentrating, and feeling overwhelmed - these are symptoms of clinical depression. This isn't a personal failing; it's a medical condition that can affect anyone, and importantly, it's treatable. Would you like to discuss some treatment options that could help you start feeling more like yourself again?
Yes... I just want to feel like myself again. My kids need their mum back.

Your desire to get better for your children is a powerful motivator. There are several effective treatments we can explore, including therapy and medication options. But first, I'd like to make sure you have immediate support. Would it be helpful to create a safety plan together? We can include ways to cope with difficult moments and people you can reach out to when things feel overwhelming.
That would be good... I don't want to feel like this anymore.

I hear your readiness for change, and I want you to know that recovery is possible. While we work on a longer-term treatment plan, would you be willing to schedule another session for this week? We can focus on some immediate strategies to help you cope, especially during those difficult nighttime hours.
Hello Mrs. Wilson, and hello Jake. I'm Dr. Chen. I have some games and drawing materials here if you'd like to use them while we talk. Could you both tell me what brings you here today?
It's about Jake's behavior. His school called us in three times this month. His teacher says his outbursts are disrupting the whole class, and nothing seems to help.
Jake, it sounds like things have been pretty tough at school. I'd really like to hear your side of the story. What's been happening?
Everyone always blames me! The other kids start it, but I'm the one who gets in trouble! It's not fair!
That must feel really frustrating when you feel like you're being blamed unfairly. Could you tell me more about what happens with the other kids?

See? This is what happens. He gets angry so quickly, and these outbursts happen almost every day, not just at school. At home, he'll throw things, slam doors... Last week he broke his iPad during a tantrum.
It sounds like everyone's feeling pretty overwhelmed. Mrs. Wilson, could you tell me when you first started noticing these challenges?
He's always been a bit temperamental, but it's gotten much worse over the past year. He's 8 now, and it feels like he's angry all the time. Even on good days, the smallest thing can set him off.
Jake, sometimes our feelings can feel really big and hard to handle. Could you help me understand what it feels like when you get angry? Maybe we could draw it or use these emotion cards to show me?
Sometimes I don't even know why I get so mad. It's like everything just makes me angry. Then everyone gets upset with me, which makes me even angrier.
It's affecting everything. He's losing friends because of his outbursts. He got kicked off the soccer team last month. Even his little sister is afraid of him sometimes.

That must feel really hard for everyone. Jake, when you start feeling these big angry feelings, what happens in your body? Some kids feel it in their stomach, or their hands, or their chest - where do you feel it?

The outbursts are intense. He'll scream, throw things, sometimes try to break things. Yesterday it was because his sister changed the TV channel. The reaction is always way bigger than the situation warrants.
She always does that! She never asks! Nobody listens to me!

I hear you feeling really unheard and frustrated, Jake. That's a tough feeling. Based on what you've both shared today, I think I can help explain what's happening. Jake seems to be experiencing something called Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder, or DMDD. Think of it like a thermostat that's set too sensitive - it reacts very strongly to small changes in temperature. Would you both like to learn more about what this means?
Yes, please. I've been so worried that he's just... I don't know, that we've done something wrong.

This isn't anyone's fault - not Jake's, and not yours. DMDD is like having an emotion regulation system that's extra sensitive. Jake's brain is having a harder time managing strong feelings, especially anger and frustration. Just like some kids need glasses to help them see better, Jake needs some extra help managing his emotions. The good news is that we can teach him tools to help with this.
What kind of treatment? We've tried punishment, rewards, nothing seems to work.

We'll use several approaches that work well together. One is called cognitive behavioral therapy, where Jake and I will work together to create his own special 'anger toolbox.' We'll also work with you to develop strategies that can help at home. Jake, would you like to help design your toolbox? We can include things that help you feel calm and in control.
Will it help me stop getting so angry? I don't want to keep getting in trouble.

I can hear that you really want things to get better, Jake. And yes, these tools will help you handle those big angry feelings. It's like learning any new skill - it takes practice, and we'll take it one step at a time. Would you like to learn a quick calm-down trick right now that you can try when you start feeling angry?
Hello Mr. Foley. I'm Dr. O'Brien. Thank you for taking this step to come in today. What brings you here?
My family insisted. They say I have... anger issues. But people just keep pushing my buttons!

It must be frustrating to feel like others are constantly triggering your anger. Could you help me understand what these situations look like? Perhaps you could tell me about a recent time when you felt this way?
Last week at work, someone moved my desk items. I just... lost it. Flipped the whole desk over. Broke the coffee table in the break room. I don't even remember doing it, really. It just happened.
That experience of losing control and not fully remembering your actions sounds very distressing. How frequently do you find yourself experiencing these intense anger episodes?
Too often. At home, at work... Last month I put my fist through a wall because my son left his bike in the driveway. The month before that, I destroyed my neighbor's mailbox over a parking dispute.
These episodes seem to be having a significant impact on various aspects of your life. Could you tell me more about how you feel after these incidents occur?
Horrible. Ashamed. The anger just takes over, and then later I can't believe what I did. It's like... it wasn't even me. My wife's threatening to leave if I don't get help.

That combination of intense anger followed by shame and regret must be incredibly difficult to cope with. When you think about these incidents afterward, how do you feel about the size of your reaction compared to what triggered it?
No... I know they're not. A moved desk shouldn't make someone destroy an office. But in the moment, I just can't control it. It's like a switch flips.

It's important that you can recognize that these reactions are disproportionate. That awareness is actually a positive sign. Before we discuss this further, I'd like to make sure we're not missing any other factors. Have you had any physical conditions or substance use that might be contributing to these outbursts?
No, I'm healthy otherwise. Don't drink, don't do drugs. I've even had my thyroid checked - my regular doctor thought that might be it.

Thank you for being so thorough about your health. Based on what you've described - the sudden, intense outbursts, the feeling of losing control, and the disproportionate reactions - you appear to be experiencing what we call Intermittent Explosive Disorder, or IED. This is a recognized medical condition that affects the brain's ability to regulate aggressive impulses. Would you like to understand more about how this works?
There's actually a name for this? I thought I was just... broken somehow.

You're definitely not broken, Mr. Foley. IED is a real medical condition that affects many people. Think of it like a faulty circuit breaker that trips too easily. The good news is that we have effective treatments that can help you regain control and rebuild your relationships. Would you like to hear about the treatment approaches that have helped others with similar experiences?
What kind of therapy? I don't want to just sit around talking about my feelings.

I understand your concern. The therapy we use, called cognitive behavioral therapy, is actually very practical and action-oriented. We'll work on identifying your specific triggers and develop concrete strategies to handle them differently. This includes learning to recognize early warning signs in your body and having specific tools ready to use. We might also consider medications that can help make it easier to pause and think before reacting. How does that sound?
I just want to stop losing control. I'm tired of apologizing to everyone and fixing things I've broken.

That desire for change is really important, and it tells me you're ready to work on this. Would you be willing to start with therapy, and we can discuss medication options as we go? We can also talk about some immediate strategies you can start using right away.
Yes. I need to do something before I lose my family over this.

Your commitment to your family is clear, and it's a powerful motivation for change. Let's start by developing a plan to help you handle intense anger situations in the immediate future, and then we can work on longer-term strategies. Would it be helpful to schedule another session this week to begin working on these skills?
Hello Ms. Bennett. I'm Dr. Reynolds. Thank you for coming in today. I understand this must be difficult for you. Would you feel comfortable telling me what's been happening?
They're all watching me. They know what I did. The voices keep telling me I deserve this.
That sounds very distressing and frightening. Could you tell me when you first started hearing these voices? Take your time.
It started... maybe two months ago. Just whispers at first. After I lost my job. But now they're so loud... they never stop.
She was laid off three months ago. That's when I noticed her starting to withdraw. But this voice thing... that's new.
Thank you for that information. Sarah, I know the voices might be scary, but would you be able to tell me what they're saying to you? Understanding this will help me find the best way to support you.
They tell everyone about my crimes. About how I caused all the deaths. The pandemic... it's my fault. I developed the virus in my basement. All those people...
Sarah, that's impossible. You've never even worked in medicine. You were an accountant.

I can hear how real these beliefs feel to you, Sarah, and how much pain they're causing. These intense feelings of guilt must be overwhelming. Could you tell me more about what you're seeing on television?
The news... they talk about me in code. They show the death counts... it's all messages about what I did.
That must be exhausting to experience. I notice you look very tired. Have you been able to get any rest lately?
I can't sleep. They won't let me. The voices get louder at night. And when I do sleep... the dreams... so much blood on my hands...
Doctor, she hasn't eaten in three days either. Says the food is poisoned.
They're putting things in my food. To punish me. I deserve it... but I can't eat it. The voices say it will melt my organs.

I hear how frightened you are of eating, and I understand why, given what the voices are telling you. Before these experiences began, how were you feeling? I understand you lost your job - that must have been very difficult.
After losing my job... everything felt dark. Hopeless. Couldn't get out of bed. Then I started realizing the truth... about what I'd done.
She's had depression before, about five years ago, but nothing like this. She got better with medication then.
Thank you for sharing that history. Sarah, did something change with your previous medication?
The voices said the pills were part of the cover-up... to make me forget what I did. I had to stop them to face my punishment.

I understand the voices convinced you to stop the medication. That must have felt like the right thing to do at the time. I'm concerned about your safety and well-being. Have you had thoughts about harming yourself?
I can't die. They won't let me. I have to stay alive to pay for my crimes. The voices say death would be too easy.
I found her apartment completely dark today. All windows covered with aluminum foil. She said it was to block the surveillance.
They're watching me through the windows. Through the TV. Through my phone. They record everything and broadcast it.
You must feel very unsafe and exposed. How are you feeling right now in this room with us?
They're here too! In the walls! Can't you hear them? They're telling everyone what I did! Make them stop! Please!
Doctor, what's happening to my sister? Will she ever be the same?

What Sarah is experiencing is called psychotic depression. It's a severe form of depression where a person also experiences psychotic symptoms like the voices she's hearing and the beliefs about being responsible for harm. It's important to understand that these experiences, while very real to Sarah, are symptoms of an illness that can be treated.
But she's always been so logical, so rational. She's an accountant, for heaven's sake.

I understand this is very difficult to witness. Psychotic depression can affect anyone, regardless of their background or personality. What's important to know is that with proper treatment, people can and do recover. Right now, I'm recommending immediate hospitalization where we can provide Sarah with the comprehensive care she needs in a safe environment.
No, no hospital! They'll experiment on me there! The voices say they'll harvest my organs!

I hear how frightened you are about the hospital, Sarah. The voices have convinced you it's dangerous, but I want you to know that my primary concern is your safety and well-being. The hospital is a place where we can help you find relief from these distressing experiences. Would you be willing to let us try to help you feel better?
What kind of treatment are we talking about?

We use several effective treatments for psychotic depression. This includes a combination of medications that can help with both the depression and the psychotic symptoms. In some cases, we also consider electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), which can be very helpful for severe symptoms. Our first priority is getting Sarah to a safe environment where she can receive proper care and nutrition. We'll develop a comprehensive treatment plan tailored to her needs.
Will the voices stop?

Yes, Sarah. With treatment, the voices will become quieter and eventually stop. The overwhelming guilt you're feeling will also lift. Recovery takes time, but I want you to know that many people who experience what you're going through do get better. Would you be willing to take this first step with us?
Hello Mrs. Anderson. Thank you for coming today. I can see this is difficult, but you're in a safe place. Would you feel comfortable telling me what's troubling you?
I... I don't know why I'm here. My body is already dead. I'm just a shell walking around.
Mom, please... that's not true. This started about three months ago after Dad passed away. She's been saying her organs are rotting, that she can smell decay coming from inside her.
Mrs. Anderson, these must be very frightening sensations you're experiencing. Could you help me understand more about what you're feeling?
There's nothing inside anymore. My stomach dissolved weeks ago. Food just falls into empty space. I can feel the emptiness... the decay.
She's lost thirty pounds because she barely eats. Says there's no point since she has no digestive system anymore.
I hear how real these sensations are for you. Could we talk about when these feelings started? I understand you experienced a profound loss recently.
After John died... everything went dark. I couldn't get out of bed. Then I realized... I died with him. My heart stopped when his did. I just haven't fallen down yet.
The loss of your husband must be devastating. These physical sensations you're experiencing - can you tell me more about how they feel?
I can feel the rot spreading. Why can't anyone else smell it? The decay is so strong. And sometimes... sometimes I hear the worms...
Mom's always been the strong one in the family. She handled everything when Dad got sick. Then after the funeral, she just... broke.
Taking care of your husband must have required immense strength. Mrs. Anderson, with all these distressing sensations, are you able to get any rest?
The dead don't sleep. I lie there and feel my body decomposing. The worms crawl at night... they're eating what's left...
She paces all night. Says she can't lie down because the decay will spread faster. She's also been... she's been visiting Dad's grave every day, saying she needs to join him.
Mrs. Anderson, I hear the deep connection you still have with your husband. When you visit his grave and think about joining him, what goes through your mind?
I'm already dead. But I can't rest. God is punishing me. Making me walk around as a rotting corpse because I didn't save John. A good wife would have saved him.
Mom, Dad had terminal cancer. There was nothing anyone could do.
You don't understand! I can prove it! Look! You can see through my skin! The organs are gone!

Mrs. Anderson, I can see how deeply you're suffering. What you're experiencing - these intense feelings and sensations - are part of something we call psychotic depression. It often emerges after a profound loss, when grief becomes so overwhelming that it changes how we experience our own body. These feelings, while extremely real to you, are symptoms that we can help with.
Is this... is this like dementia? Is Mom losing her mind?

No, this is very different. Your mother is experiencing a severe form of depression that includes beliefs about her body, triggered by the profound trauma of losing your father. This condition is called Cotard's syndrome when it accompanies depression, and importantly, it responds well to treatment.
No medicine can help a corpse. I should be buried with John...

I understand that right now, these sensations feel absolutely real to you. Your grief for John is so intense that it's affected how you experience your own body. Because you're having these thoughts about joining your husband, I believe you need immediate care in a safe environment where we can help you begin to heal.
What kind of treatment?

We'll use a comprehensive approach that includes medications to help with both the depression and these distressing bodily sensations. We might also consider ECT (electroconvulsive therapy), which can be remarkably effective in cases like this. Throughout treatment, we'll also provide support for processing grief in a healthier way.
But my heart isn't beating... how can anything help?

Mrs. Anderson, would you be willing to try something with me? I have my stethoscope here, and I'd like you to listen to your own heartbeat. Sometimes hearing it can be a first step toward reconnecting with your body. May I?
But... I don't understand... I felt it stop...

That heartbeat you're hearing is real, Mrs. Anderson. You are alive, even though right now you're experiencing life through the lens of profound grief. With treatment and support, you can begin to feel connected to life again. Would you be willing to take this first step toward healing with us?
Hello Ms. Clark. Thank you for coming in today. Many people find it difficult to seek help for seasonal changes. What brings you here?
It's happening again. Every year as soon as the days get shorter, I just... I feel like I'm shutting down.
That must be really challenging, knowing this pattern is starting again. Could you tell me more about what 'shutting down' feels like for you?
It's like clockwork. Around October, I start sleeping more and more. Can't get out of bed in the morning. I'm constantly craving carbs - I've gained 10 pounds already. I just want to hibernate.
You've described this pattern very clearly. Understanding when these changes began can help us develop the best treatment plan. When did you first notice this seasonal pattern?

I noticed it first when I moved from Florida to Minnesota five years ago. The winters here... they're so dark. By December, I can barely function. Then spring comes, and it's like a fog lifting. I feel normal again.
That transition from Florida to Minnesota must have been quite an adjustment. How do these seasonal changes affect your daily routine and activities?
I used to go to the gym, meet friends for coffee. Now I just go to work and come straight home. I'm in bed by 7 PM most nights. My friends have stopped inviting me places because I always cancel.
It sounds like these changes significantly impact your social life and daily activities. You mentioned feeling better in spring - could you describe that transition?
Yes, completely. By April, I'm back to my old self. I have energy, I socialize, I eat normally. It's like I'm two different people - summer me and winter me.
That's a very insightful way to describe it. During the winter months, how would you describe your emotional state? Not just energy levels, but your overall mood?
Just... flat. Not necessarily sad, but nothing brings me joy. It's like all the color drains from the world. Sometimes I wonder if I should just move back to Florida.
That feeling of the world losing its color is a powerful description. Have you noticed any connection between your symptoms and your exposure to natural sunlight?
Definitely. On rare sunny winter days, I feel a bit better. But I leave for work in the dark and come home in the dark. Sometimes I realize I haven't seen the sun in days.

Thank you for sharing these observations. What you're describing aligns with a condition called Seasonal Affective Disorder, or SAD. It's a form of depression that follows a seasonal pattern, strongly influenced by light exposure. The symptoms you've described - increased sleep, carb cravings, low energy, and mood changes - are all classic signs of SAD. Have you heard of this condition before?
I've read about it online, but wasn't sure if it was a real diagnosis. You mean this is an actual condition?

Yes, absolutely. SAD is a well-documented form of depression that affects many people, particularly in northern regions with significant seasonal light changes. The good news is that we have several effective treatment options that can help you maintain your quality of life throughout the winter months. Would you like to explore these options?
Please. I'm dreading going through another winter like this.

I understand that dread, and I want to help you face this winter with more tools and support. One of our most effective treatments is light therapy, which involves using a special bright light box that mimics natural daylight. The light box is designed to help regulate your body's internal clock and boost mood-related brain chemicals. We can also discuss other strategies, including antidepressant medications if needed. Would you like to learn more about how light therapy works?
The light box sounds interesting. How long would I need to use it?

Typically, we recommend 20-30 minutes each morning, ideally soon after waking up. We would also want to develop a comprehensive plan that includes other evidence-based strategies, such as maintaining a regular sleep schedule, getting exercise during daylight hours when possible, and making some dietary adjustments. Some people also find vitamin D supplementation helpful, though we'd want to check your levels first. How does this approach sound to you?
Could we try the light therapy first before considering medication?

Absolutely. Let's start with light therapy and lifestyle modifications, and closely monitor how you respond. I'll show you how to track your symptoms so we can adjust the treatment plan if needed. Would you like to schedule a follow-up in two weeks to see how you're responding to the light therapy? We can always discuss additional options if needed.
Doctor, my sister hasn't spoken in three days. She just... sits there. Sometimes in the same position for hours. This isn't like her at all.
I can hear how worried you are about these changes. Let's work together to understand what's happening. Could you tell me when you first started noticing these changes in your sister?
It started gradually. She's been depressed for months after losing her job, but last week... it was like she just shut down. She stopped responding to questions, wouldn't eat unless we fed her.
Thank you for bringing her in. These changes must be very frightening to witness. Besides the job loss, has your sister experienced any other significant stresses or changes recently?
Our mother passed away two months ago. That's when the depression really got bad. But this... this complete withdrawal, it started after she attended a grief support group last week.

I'm very sorry about your mother. That's a significant loss for both of you. Ms. Johnson, if you can hear me, I'm Dr. Mitchell. I'm here to help. I'm going to check your arm now to better understand what's happening.
[Observation: The psychiatrist gently lifts the patient's arm. It remains in the raised position even after being released, demonstrating waxy flexibility.]

I notice your sister maintains positions when her limbs are moved. This is an important clinical sign. Have you observed any other unusual movements or behaviors that seem different from her typical depression?

Sometimes she makes these faces, like grimaces. And yesterday, when I tried to help her up, she did the opposite of everything I was trying to do. It was like she was actively resisting, but in an odd way.

What you're describing helps us understand what's happening. Your sister is experiencing what we call catatonic depression. The resistance you noticed, called negativism, along with her silence and the way she maintains positions, are all symptoms of catatonia occurring alongside severe depression. This is a serious condition, but importantly, it's one we can treat.
Is... is this permanent? Will she ever speak again?

I understand how frightening this must be, but I want to assure you that catatonic depression is treatable. Many patients respond well to treatment, often showing improvement within days. We'll start with a medication called lorazepam, which can help relatively quickly with catatonic symptoms. We'll monitor her closely and may consider additional treatments if needed.
Electroconvulsive therapy? Isn't that dangerous?

I appreciate that concern - many people have similar worries about ECT. Modern electroconvulsive therapy is very different from what you might have seen in movies or heard about from the past. It's now a safe, carefully controlled procedure that can be remarkably effective for catatonic depression, especially when other treatments aren't providing enough relief. Would you like me to explain more about how modern ECT works?
[Observation: Patient shows slight eye movement toward sister for the first time during conversation.]

I notice your sister just moved her eyes toward you - that's actually a positive sign. Even small responses can indicate potential for improvement. Given the severity of her symptoms, I recommend she be admitted to the hospital where we can ensure her safety, monitor her nutrition, and begin treatment immediately. We'll be able to provide round-the-clock care and adjust her treatment as needed.
How long might she need to stay?

While every person's recovery is different, many patients with catatonic depression begin showing improvement within days of starting treatment. We'll monitor her response to medication very carefully. I'll make sure you're updated regularly on her progress, and we can discuss visiting hours and how you can best support her during treatment. The most important thing right now is getting her the intensive care she needs. Would you like to know more about what to expect during her hospital stay?

Hello Mrs. Mitchell. Thank you for coming in today. I understand your obstetrician referred you. Many new mothers find it difficult to seek help, so you've taken an important step. Would you like to tell me what's been concerning you?
I... I don't know what's wrong with me. I should be happy. Emma is perfect, but I just... I can't stop crying.
It takes courage to share these feelings. Many new mothers experience similar struggles. Could you tell me when you first started noticing these feelings?
It started gradually. The first few weeks, everyone said it was just baby blues. But it's gotten worse. I can barely get out of bed. My husband has to force me to eat.
That sounds really difficult. Could you help me understand what a typical day looks like for you and Emma?
That's the worst part. I can't... I can't seem to connect with her. Sometimes I don't feed her until she's screaming because I just lie there, paralyzed. What kind of mother does that?
I hear the pain and guilt in your voice. These feelings don't make you a bad mother - they're symptoms of a medical condition that we can treat. How are you managing with sleep when Emma sleeps?
I can't sleep, even though I'm exhausted. I lie awake checking if she's breathing. Or sometimes I sleep too much and my husband has to wake me to feed her. I keep having these horrible thoughts...
Many new mothers have distressing thoughts they're afraid to share. Could you tell me more about these thoughts?

Sometimes... sometimes I think Emma would be better off without me. That I'm ruining her. Last week, I stood at the top of the stairs holding her, and... I got so scared of my thoughts I gave her to my husband and locked myself in the bathroom.

Thank you for trusting me with this. You did exactly the right thing by giving Emma to your husband when you felt overwhelmed. I want to make sure you're both safe. Are you having thoughts of harming yourself or Emma?
I would never hurt her. But sometimes I think about hurting myself. I don't want to, but the thoughts keep coming.
It's important that you're telling me this. Let's talk about your support system at home. Who's available to help you?
My husband tries, but he has to work. My mom wants to help, but seeing her with Emma... how natural she is... it just makes me feel worse. Like I'm broken somehow.
Those comparisons can be really painful. Have you been able to breastfeed, or has that been a challenge?
I tried, but I couldn't produce enough milk. Another failure. The lactation consultant said it was probably stress, but formula feeding makes me feel even more inadequate.
Fed is best - whether it's breast milk or formula. Before Emma, had you ever experienced similar feelings of depression or anxiety?
No, never. I was so excited about the pregnancy. I had everything planned. The nursery was perfect. Now I can barely look at all those carefully chosen things.

What you're experiencing is postpartum depression, a serious but treatable medical condition that affects many new mothers. It's not a reflection of your worth as a mother, and it's not your fault. The negative thoughts and feelings you're having are symptoms of this condition, just like a fever is a symptom of infection.
Will I feel like this forever? I'm afraid I'm damaging Emma.

No, you won't feel like this forever. Postpartum depression responds well to treatment, and many mothers see significant improvement. I recommend we start a comprehensive treatment plan that includes both medication and therapy. The earlier we start treatment, the better for both you and Emma.
Is it safe to take medication if I'm occasionally still trying to breastfeed?

Yes, there are several antidepressants that are safe during breastfeeding. We'll choose one that's been well-studied in nursing mothers. Your health is crucial for Emma's well-being. Would you feel comfortable trying medication as part of your treatment?
I'll try anything. I just want to feel like myself again. To be the mother Emma deserves.

Let's create a comprehensive plan to help you get there. I'd like to see you weekly at first to monitor your progress closely. We'll start with an antidepressant that's safe for breastfeeding, and begin interpersonal therapy to help you navigate this transition to motherhood. I also want to connect you with a postpartum support group where you can meet other mothers who understand what you're going through. Would you like to hear more about each part of this treatment plan?
Hello Laura. Thank you for coming in today. I understand you've been experiencing some intense concerns since discovering your pregnancy. Could you tell me what's been troubling you?
Doctor, I made a terrible mistake. I drank beer and used nail ointment before I knew I was pregnant. The baby must be damaged. I need an abortion, but no one will listen to me.
I hear how distressed you are about this. These worries must be overwhelming. Have you had any medical evaluations to address these concerns?
I've been to every hospital in the city. They all say everything's fine, but they must be wrong. How can they be so sure? I keep checking and rechecking, but I can't trust their results.

This pattern of repeatedly seeking reassurance sounds quite exhausting. You've mentioned having similar experiences before. How do these current concerns compare to your previous experiences with checking behaviors during exams?
This is different. Back then, I knew I was being excessive with checking doors and arranging things. But now... I KNOW something is wrong with this baby. I'm completely sure of it.
Your conviction about this feels very different to you. Could you help me understand what makes you so certain?

Everything must be perfect. A baby should be perfect. Any exposure to anything harmful means the baby will be damaged. It's logical, isn't it? My husband doesn't understand. He just wants a baby before his father dies, but I can't bring an imperfect child into the world.
The word 'perfect' seems very important in your thinking. Has striving for perfection been a significant part of your life experience?
Ever since my mother died... I've needed everything to be exactly right. But this is different. This isn't about arranging books or checking locks. This is about a life.
Losing your mother must have deeply affected how you view the world. With all these intense worries, how are you managing to rest?

I barely sleep. I spend nights researching everything that could go wrong, looking for proof. When doctors say the tests are normal, I think they're hiding something. Sometimes I think they're all conspiring to make me have this baby.

That must be exhausting and frightening - feeling like you can't trust the medical professionals. These thoughts seem more intense than your previous experiences. Is there any part of you that wonders if these fears might be excessive?
No. This isn't like before. This isn't OCD. I'm preventing a tragedy. Sometimes I think... if no one will help me prevent it now, I might have to fix it after the baby is born.
When you say 'fix it,' could you tell me more about what you mean?
Sometimes I think about ways to end its suffering... after it's born. If it's imperfect as I know it will be... wouldn't that be more merciful?

I hear how much pain you're in, and I'm very concerned about the intensity of these thoughts. In the past, medication helped you manage similar distressing thoughts. Would you be willing to discuss medication options that are safe during pregnancy?
No medications! They might harm the baby. Don't you understand? Everything that enters my body will damage it more. I just need someone to believe me and help me end this pregnancy.

Laura, I'm hearing that these thoughts have become overwhelming and are affecting your ability to trust medical care. While your previous OCD focused on checking and arranging, pregnancy has triggered more severe symptoms. I'm very concerned about your safety and well-being right now.
You're like all the others. You won't help me. You don't understand that this isn't OCD anymore. This is about preventing a disaster. I know I'm right!

Your distress is very real, and you deserve immediate support and care. Given the intensity of these thoughts and concerns about safety, I believe you need a higher level of care right now. I'd like to discuss having you stay in our specialized maternal mental health unit where we can provide the comprehensive support you need during this difficult time. Would you be willing to hear more about how this could help?
The worst symptom is my fear of peanuts definitely. That's what I think about a lot of the time, when I'm out and about, looking around. I seem to be expecting them to be everywhere.
Could you tell me more about how these fears affect your daily life?

The other problems are my fear of any other thing that could hurt me at all. Like, both in glass for example. I had a watch and the battery leaked, and I got completely terrified of wearing it again even though I was told that it had been cleaned and everything. I was terrified that it was still there and going to hurt me.
It sounds like these fears have created significant challenges for you. How has this changed your daily routines?

They ruined my life. My life completely changed. I just don't think in the same way as I used to. I'm just worried all the time, always worried about something I might have touched or come into contact with. It moves on continuously from day to day, something new every day that I'm scared about.
I hear how much these fears have impacted your life. Could you tell me more about what specifically worries you about these substances?

The fear with all these things isn't just touching them. Every single time, it's a fear that I'm going to somehow get it in my mouth. That's the big fear. It's alright touching things, but if I get something in my mouth, that's what I'm scared of. Scared of ingesting something, and I'm scared of not being able to breathe.

I'm washing all the time. My hands are a mess. I do that because if I think I've touched something that's going to hurt me, then just to be sure I'll wash my hands and I feel safe again. Just washing my hands sort of gets rid of whatever could have touched them. Then I can eat or touch my mouth if my hands have been washed. If they haven't, there's no way I could do that. I can't touch my lips even. I get scared if I do.
Thank you for sharing these details. Understanding your specific fears helps us plan treatment effectively. How frequently do you find yourself needing to wash your hands?
I have no idea. All through the day, several times an hour.
Could you tell me about when these fears first started developing?

Well, it was already my second attempt at doing the year in France that was part of my course. I was going to do a course at the university, and I was very frightened because I'd already had one try to go out - my dad came with me. I'd been too frightened and had to come back home again. I couldn't handle the thought of being by myself, having a flat all by myself.

I found a place to live, flat with a few other people. But I didn't really know any of them at the beginning. And then this fear started really suddenly because the flat was really dirty. I was disgusted by how dirty the flat was, especially the bathroom.

It started when I tried to always go and have a bath and come back to my room to get dressed, but the bathroom was so filthy, and the bathroom floor had mud and stuff on it. I always had to walk through the bathroom to get back to my room, and my feet would get all filthy. I'd have to go back to the bathroom to clean again, but I'd have to walk through the mud to get back out. It was a vicious circle.
That sounds like a really overwhelming situation. How has this affected your relationships?

I get depressed when I start thinking I'm never going to get better. And I get depressed when he starts getting down about it. As long as he can cope, I'm usually just about okay. But sometimes he can't cope. And when he starts getting upset, then I just completely lose it, go to pieces.

Because there's the additional fear on top of everything else that he's not going to be able to cope with me and that the relationship is going to completely fall apart. I get really frightened at what I'm doing to him. I'm not the person he thought I was when we first met. I have changed since then, and I want to be able to just be the person I used to be.

I understand your desire to return to your former self. Today, we're going to take a small but important step toward that goal. I'm going to introduce exposure therapy, which has helped many people overcome similar fears. Would you be willing to start with something small, like looking at a sealed peanut packet?
No... but obviously I'd be more panicked if it was open. I'm still nervous about it.
That's perfectly normal to feel nervous. Let's just sit with that feeling for a moment. Notice if your anxiety changes as you look at the packet. Remember, you're in control here.
If I was at home and did this, I'd rush to the basin and wash my hands. I sort of feel safe here. I couldn't do this at home.
That feeling of safety is important. Would you feel comfortable if we took another small step? What if I open the wrapper?
No, no way!
I understand your fear. Remember, we move at your pace. What if we try something smaller? What if I touch the peanut and then touch your hand? You can say no if it feels too overwhelming.
I actually did it. I touched peanuts. Something I thought I'd never be able to do.
That's a remarkable achievement. You've shown incredible courage today. This is how progress happens - one small step at a time. Would you like to talk about what this experience was like for you?
Nice to see you again, Tom. It's been quite a while - about four years since your GAP year, right? I understand you were recently in hospital? How are you feeling about being back?
Yeah. I'd been doing well for years, kept it under control. It was disappointing to go through it all again.

Four years of stability is significant. While this setback is understandably disappointing, it's important to remember that recovery isn't always linear. Could you tell me about what was happening before things started to change?

It started towards the end of university. I was doing law, on track for a first. Final exams were coming up, and I felt like this was really my time, you know? Started working longer hours, sleeping less.
That was a high-pressure situation. Looking back, what strategies did you try to use to manage those increased demands?

Started with coffee, lots of it. Then energy drinks, coffee tablets. Everyone was pushing themselves. Some people were taking Ritalin, so I... I started taking that too. It seemed necessary at the time.
That gradual progression is important to note. How did these stimulants affect your mood and energy levels?
At first it was great. I became more productive, more confident. My brain was working faster. It felt like everything was building up momentum. I was finally becoming who I was meant to be.
That sense of becoming your 'true self' can be very compelling. During this time, how were your sleep patterns changing?
It started at about six hours, then five, eventually down to two or three. But I didn't need it. The less I slept, the more I could do. My thoughts were firing, my goals were stronger.
That decreasing need for sleep is a significant pattern. What happened after the pressure of exams was lifted?

That's when things really took off. Started going out every night. Cocaine, MDMA, whatever was around. I was on cloud nine. I was the person everyone wanted to know - I put myself at the center of the universe.
During this elevated state, were there any significant decisions or changes you made that stand out now?

I convinced my friend to develop this app - it was going to calculate the most cost-effective way to get wasted when you're in a liquor store. Spent loads of my parents' savings, got a secret credit card. Bought clothes, drugs, invested in tech...
Those kinds of financial and social decisions can have lasting impacts. How did this period affect your close relationships?
I had a girlfriend then, but... I was the main character, you know? Nobody else really mattered. On nights out, she wouldn't even be in my mind. There were... others.
Now that you have some distance from that time, how do you reflect on those experiences and their impact?
Those moments where it's not just me suffering... those closest to you have to suffer too. That brings a lot of the shame.
That insight about the ripple effects on others is valuable. When you think back, what were the earliest signs that things were shifting?

That's the thing - I didn't. Everything felt perfect. I thought I was finally becoming the person I was meant to be. All my parents' work, all my work... it was all coming together. I was the master of the situation.
Given this experience, how do you think we can work together to help you recognize and respond to early warning signs in the future?

I need to confront the symptoms earlier. At university, I'd managed so well that it wasn't part of my world anymore. When things started changing, I just let it take hold instead of recognizing what was happening.

That's a valuable insight. Would you be interested in developing a more detailed relapse prevention plan? We could identify specific triggers, early warning signs, and concrete steps to take when you notice them. This could include who to contact and what interventions have helped in the past.
Hello. My name is Jade, I'm one of the doctors on your ward. Could I check your name and date of birth, please?
Yeah. Of course. So it's Yvonne, Yvonne Hart, and it's third of May nineteen sixty eight.
Thank you for confirming that, Yvonne. Could you help me understand what brought you to the hospital today?
Oh, yeah. Goodness knows why, but actually, blame my husband. That's how I blame my husband, but no idea what I'm here, but as sooner I can get out the better because I have got things to do.
It sounds like you have some important things you need to attend to. Could you tell me more about what you're working on?

Oh, so many things! I've got all these inventions, you see. Revolutionary stuff. I've been chosen by the royal family to share them with the world. Charles himself - very clever man, Charles - he's given me these special powers.
These sound like significant responsibilities. I'd like to understand how you've been managing with everything. How have you been feeling recently?
I have been feeling absolutely fantastic. Never felt as good. In fact, it's the best I've felt, I would say the best I felt in my entire life. Yep. Feeling great.
And is this level of energy usual for you? How would you describe your typical mood?

Well, to be honest, I've had so many times where I've just been down in the dumps, miserable as miserable can be, depressed, fed up with life, but not now! I have so many ideas, so many inventions to share!
With all these ideas and energy, I wonder how your sleep has been affected?
Don't need sleep! I have so much energy. All these ideas just swimming around in my head. Don't need sleep, and I think I look rather good actually, even without any sleep.
Managing all these activities must take a lot of energy. Have you been able to maintain regular meals?
Who has time to eat? No desire to eat, haven't got time! I need to use all my time to write and get these patents!
You've mentioned patents several times. I'd be interested to hear more about your inventions.

Well, my biggest one is the cure for cancer. It just came to me while I was walking. But I can't tell you exactly what it is - someone's stolen my suitcase with all the information. They're going to profit from my work!
That sounds very frustrating. How do you think you might handle the situation with the missing suitcase?

I'd have strong words with them, yes. I mean, I'm not a violent person, but I would give them a piece of my mind. The royal family would have them sent to the Tower! But no, no, I wouldn't harm them. I'm peaceful.
Have there been any changes in your usual activities or behaviors recently that others have commented on?

Well, my husband says I've been taking risks, but honestly, I haven't at all. I was just in a rush to get to the patent office - had to speed a bit. Now he's taken away my keys! How am I supposed to get my work done?
I notice you're very certain about these special abilities and responsibilities. Have you considered any other explanations for these recent changes?

Absolutely not. I am the chosen one. The royal family selected me specifically. It's my destiny, and I have these powers of exceptional intelligence now. My husband's just jealous - he'll see when I'm famous!
To help me understand your current situation better, could you tell me what time it is now?
I think it's about three o'clock.
And could you confirm where we are at the moment?
Yes, I'm in hospital, but I shouldn't be here. I should be out there showing people my inventions!

I understand you're eager to continue with your work. Right now, our priority is ensuring your wellbeing. Could we discuss how we might work together to help you feel more comfortable during your stay here?
Thank you for coming in today. I understand you've been under psychiatric care for quite some time. Could you tell me about your experience with mental health services?
Yes, since my son was born. I'm not even sure why I'm still coming. Nothing really changes.
It sounds like you've had some disappointing experiences with treatment. Could you help me understand what hasn't been helpful in your previous care?
They've called it everything - postpartum depression, bipolar, personality disorder. Nothing fits. Nothing helps.
Having multiple diagnoses without finding helpful treatment must be frustrating. I notice there was a period when you were hospitalized. Would you feel comfortable telling me about that experience?

That was when I was 36. I got involved with this man... he... He took everything from me. Made me sell my apartment, write a will. They said I was paranoid, but my son confirmed later - he was a criminal. He went to prison.
That sounds like a terrifying experience, and it must have been especially difficult when people didn't believe you. How were you coping during that time?
I was all over the place. Couldn't sleep, felt angry, started cutting myself. They said I was manic, but I was just... terrified. They didn't believe me about him.
Those reactions make sense given what you were going through. Could you tell me about your current medication and how it's working for you?
Lamotrigine, 200mg. Been on it for four years. Before that, I went seven years without any medication. Didn't make much difference either way.
I understand you mentioned your father had mental health challenges. Could you tell me more about your early experiences?
Yes... he was hospitalized too. Had ECT. Sometimes he'd talk in rhymes, other times just stare into space. I tried to kill myself with his pills when I was nine.
I'm so sorry you went through that at such a young age. If you feel able, could you tell me what was happening that led to such deep despair?
My brother was... hurting me. Mom said she couldn't leave dad because of us kids. I thought if I wasn't there... The abuse had been going on for three years by then.
You were carrying such a heavy burden at such a young age. No child should have to endure that. How do these experiences influence your relationships now?
After that criminal, I stayed single for 15 years. Now I have someone, but... we keep things distant. Five years together and we've never been to each other's homes. I prefer it that way.
That distance sounds like it helps you feel safe. Do you sometimes find memories of the past intruding into your present?
They come without warning. But I've learned to watch them like a movie. Not feel them. There are still blank spots - whole months I can't remember.
Disconnecting from feelings can be a way of protecting yourself. How do you manage when emotions do break through?
I shut down. It's easier not to feel anything. That's why they thought I was bipolar - when I do feel things, they overwhelm me. I either explode or collapse.
These responses often develop as ways to cope with trauma. Have you ever had the opportunity to work with a trauma-focused therapist?
No. They kept focusing on my mood swings, my 'personality problems.' Nobody asked about the past. I learned to stop mentioning it.

I hear how your past experiences have been overlooked, which must have felt invalidating. Would you be interested in exploring trauma-focused therapy? There are approaches specifically designed to help process these experiences at a pace that feels safe for you.
Thank you for coming in today. I know taking this step can be difficult. I understand you've been experiencing some challenges lately?
Yes. I was in a car accident three months ago. I thought I'd be over it by now, but things seem to be getting worse.
There's no set timeline for processing traumatic experiences. Could you tell me how this experience has been affecting your daily life?
I keep seeing it happen, over and over. Even when I'm just sitting at my desk at work, suddenly I'm back there, hearing the crash, smelling the smoke...
These vivid memories must be very distressing. When they occur, do they feel different from regular memories of the accident?
They're so real. Like it's happening right now. My heart races, I start sweating. Sometimes I don't even realize I'm at work until a colleague snaps me out of it.
These sound like flashbacks, where past experiences feel very present. Have you noticed yourself changing your routines or avoiding certain situations to cope with these experiences?
I haven't driven since. I take long detours to avoid the intersection where it happened. I've been working from home more because my office is on that route.
Those changes are common responses to trauma. When you think about the accident, are there parts that remain unclear or difficult to recall?
There are gaps. I remember the impact, but everything between that and the ambulance arriving is just... blank. Maybe I don't want to remember.
Memory gaps are also a normal response to trauma. How have these experiences affected how you view yourself?
I keep thinking I should have seen the other car coming. If I'd been more alert... I know it wasn't my fault, but I feel like I failed somehow.
It's common to question past actions after a traumatic event, but it doesn't mean you're at fault. Have you noticed changes in how you respond to your environment?
I'm constantly on edge. Any sudden noise makes me jump. I sit facing the door in restaurants. I can't focus because I'm always scanning for danger.
This heightened alertness is your body's way of trying to keep you safe. How has this been affecting your relationships with others?
I've been pushing people away. My family wants to help, but I can't stand their worried looks. It's easier to be alone than explain why I flinch at every car horn.
Isolation can feel protective, but it can also make recovery more challenging. Have you found yourself using any particular ways to cope with these feelings?
I've been drinking more than usual. Just to help me sleep. The nightmares are... I wake up screaming sometimes.

Thank you for being honest about that. Sleep disruption and nightmares are common after trauma, and it's understandable to seek relief. Would you be interested in learning some safer strategies to help manage these symptoms? There are several effective approaches we could explore together.
Thank you for coming in today. Could you tell me what brings you here?
I lost my job six months ago. After 25 years of service, they just... replaced me with someone younger. Called it 'restructuring.' I can't get past it.
Twenty-five years is a significant part of your life. This must feel like much more than just losing a job. Could you tell me more about how this experience has affected you?
I'm consumed by anger. Every morning I wake up thinking about how they betrayed me. Sometimes I fantasize about making them pay, showing them how wrong they were.
Your anger is understandable given the depth of this betrayal. Could you help me understand when you first noticed these feelings becoming so intense?
The moment they called me into that office. Everything changed in that instant. I was a different person walking out than walking in.
That moment seems to have been deeply traumatic for you. When you think about that meeting now, what emotions and sensations come up?

My blood boils. Even now, talking about it... The humiliation. They treated my entire career like it meant nothing. I've started avoiding my old colleagues, can't stand seeing them continue their lives while mine is destroyed.
The sense of humiliation and injustice feels very present. How are these intense feelings impacting your daily life and relationships?
I can barely sleep. I've stopped caring about my health. Why bother? My wife says I've changed, become bitter. She doesn't understand - how could she? Nobody understands this injustice.
It sounds very isolating to carry these feelings alone. When you think about moving forward from this experience, what comes to mind?

Future? Everything I believed about loyalty, hard work, fairness - it was all a lie. I spend hours plotting ways to expose them, to make them suffer like I'm suffering. Sometimes I think about ending it all, but not before I get justice.

I hear how much pain and betrayal you're carrying, and I'm concerned about these thoughts of suicide and revenge. While these feelings are understandable given what you've experienced, I want to make sure you're safe. Could we talk about ways to help you cope with these intense emotions that won't put you at risk?
Thank you for coming in today. I understand this step wasn't easy for you, and I appreciate your willingness to talk.
My doctor insisted. Says I'm 'stuck in anger.' But wouldn't anyone be angry after what they did to me?
Your anger sounds completely understandable given what you've experienced. Could you help me understand what happened?

I was a university professor for 30 years. Published, respected, dedicated my entire life to academia. Then last year, this new department head comes in. Young, ambitious, talking about 'modernization' and 'fresh perspectives.'
Three decades of building a career in academia - that's a significant part of your identity. What happened when this change in leadership occurred?

They started questioning my teaching methods, my research focus. Called it 'outdated.' Can you believe it? Three decades of excellence, and suddenly I'm obsolete? They forced me into early retirement. Said they needed to 'make way for new blood.'
That kind of dismissal of your life's work must have been incredibly painful. Could you tell me more about how that moment impacted you?
It was like a switch flipped. One minute I was Professor Davis, respected scholar. The next, I was nothing. Worthless. Thirty years of dedication, reduced to a budget line item.
The loss of not just a job, but an entire professional identity - that's a profound trauma. How have you been managing since this happened?

I can't stop thinking about it. Every morning I wake up planning ways to expose them. I've started documenting everything - their procedural violations, their biases. I've filed complaints, written to the board, the education ministry. I'll show everyone what they really are.
I hear how consuming this has become. How has this focus on seeking justice affected your relationships?

My wife left three months ago. Said she couldn't handle my 'obsession.' My children barely visit. They don't understand that this isn't just about a job - it's about justice. About dignity. Sometimes I drive past the campus, imagining scenarios...
I'm hearing the deep isolation you're experiencing. Could you tell me more about these scenarios you imagine?
Making them pay. Exposing them publicly. Sometimes I think about more... direct approaches. I dream about confronting that department head, making him feel as helpless as I did.
These thoughts of revenge seem to be taking a significant toll on you. How are you managing to care for yourself through this?

Cope? I don't sleep anymore. I've stopped taking my blood pressure medication - what's the point? My whole life was academia. Everything I believed in - merit, scholarship, loyalty - it was all a lie. They took everything from me, and they're going to keep doing it to others unless someone stops them.
I'm concerned about your well-being. When you say 'what's the point,' have you had thoughts about ending your life?

Sometimes I think the world would be better off... but not before I get justice. I won't let them win. I can't let this stand. Sometimes I think about taking them down with me. Show them what it feels like to lose everything.

I hear the depth of your pain and sense of injustice. I'm very concerned about your safety and the thoughts you're having. Before we discuss what justice might look like, I think we need to focus on ensuring your immediate safety. Would you be willing to work with me on a plan to help keep you safe while we address these intense feelings?

Public humiliation. Forcing them to admit what they did. I want that department head to experience what I experienced. I want the board to see how they destroyed a dedicated professor's life. I've got nothing left to lose now.

Your desire for acknowledgment and vindication is understandable, but I'm hearing statements that suggest you might be at risk of harming yourself or others. Given the intensity of these feelings, I believe we need to focus first on your immediate safety. Would you be willing to discuss hospitalization? This could give you a safe space to process these emotions while ensuring everyone's safety.
Welcome to the therapy session. Could you tell me what brings you here today?
I just can't stay awake. No matter how much I sleep - 9, 10, even 12 hours - I'm still exhausted during the day. It's affecting my job.
That must be very challenging. Could you tell me when you first noticed these symptoms and how they've progressed?
About eight months now. At first, I thought it was just stress, but it's getting worse. I fall asleep at my desk, during meetings. Last week I almost dozed off while driving.
The driving incident sounds concerning. I'd like to understand your sleep patterns better. Could you walk me through your typical sleep schedule?
I go to bed around 10 PM and sleep until 8 AM. But waking up is horrible - I feel confused, almost drunk. My partner says I'm combative when they try to wake me.
That difficulty waking up is important information. What about during the day - do you find yourself needing to nap?
Multiple times, I can't help it. But they don't help at all. I wake up feeling just as foggy, sometimes worse. Yesterday I napped for three hours and still felt exhausted.
These unrefreshing naps are notable. Besides the sleepiness, have you experienced any other symptoms or unusual sensations?
My mind feels slow, like I'm thinking through mud. I get headaches, and sometimes I see things that aren't there when I'm really tired. My appetite is gone too.
The visual experiences and cognitive changes are important to note. How are these symptoms impacting your daily activities and relationships?
I've had to take medical leave from work. I can't concentrate, can't remember things. My friends think I'm avoiding them because I keep canceling plans - I'm just too exhausted to go out.
This is clearly having a significant impact on your life. Are you aware of any sleep disorders or related medical conditions in your family?
My sister has thyroid problems, and my father had sleep apnea. But this feels different. I just feel like I'm living in a fog that never lifts.

Given your symptoms - the excessive daytime sleepiness, unrefreshing sleep, sleep attacks, and morning confusion - I think we should conduct a comprehensive sleep evaluation. This would include overnight sleep monitoring and a Multiple Sleep Latency Test to measure your daytime sleepiness. Would you be willing to participate in these assessments?
Good morning, I'm Dr. Johnson. Thank you for coming in today. I know it takes a lot of courage to be here. Can you tell me a little about what's been going on?
Hi Dr. Johnson. I... I tried to hurt myself. My family brought me here after I cut my wrist. I just feel so ugly, like a monster. I can't take it anymore.

I'm so sorry you're in so much pain. That must be an overwhelming feeling. Please know that you're in a safe place here, and my role is to support you without judgment. When you say you feel like a monster, can you tell me more about what you mean by that?

It's my skin, my pores. They're huge, completely deformed. I know everyone's staring at them, laughing at how ugly I am. I've tried everything to fix it - soaps, medications, special diets. I'm always checking the mirror, sometimes for hours. But nothing helps. The doctors won't even do a skin graft because they say it looks normal. But how can they not see it?!
It sounds like these thoughts about your appearance have really consumed your life. I can hear how much anguish this is causing you. When did you first start noticing these concerns about your pores?

Around two years ago. I had some normal teenage acne, but then my pores seemed to get bigger and bigger. Now I feel like I can't even be around people. I stopped going to classes. What's the point with a face like this?

This is so hard, and I'm glad you're sharing this with me. It's clear you're suffering deeply. I want you to know these feelings aren't your fault. Have you heard of body dysmorphic disorder? It's where someone becomes extremely preoccupied with a perceived flaw in their appearance, even if that flaw seems minor or unnoticeable to others. The obsessive thoughts can feel very real and distressing. Does any of that resonate with what you're experiencing?
I've read about that online, but...I don't know. I feel like what I'm seeing has to be real. How could it not be? The mirror doesn't lie.

I understand that feeling. Our minds can fixate on certain perceptions that feel so convincing, it's hard to consider other possibilities. But sometimes, especially when those thoughts lead to this level of pain and isolation, it's helpful to step back and open up to expert support. We have treatments, including therapy and medication, that can significantly improve these symptoms. I know it may not feel like it now, but healing is possible.
I want to believe that, I do. I just feel so hopeless after trying so many things. What if nothing works? What if I'm stuck like this forever?

Those fears are completely understandable, especially with what you've been through. Recovery is a process, and it's okay if it feels daunting right now. But I want to assure you that you don't have to go through this alone anymore. I'll be here to support you every step of the way, and we'll work together to find the tools that help you start to feel better. You are so much more than how you feel about your appearance.
