With compassionate treatment, it is absolutely possible to find relief and reclaim your life. What questions do you have as we begin this journey together?
Okay. I guess... what do we do first? I just want to feel like myself again. Or at least some version of myself I can live with.

Let's start by putting together a personalized treatment plan. I'd like to have you meet with our team psychiatrist to discuss medication options that can help reduce some of the obsessive thoughts and anxiety. We'll also set up regular therapy sessions where you can process what you're feeling in a trusting environment and learn coping strategies. In the meantime, I'm also going to connect you with our support groups, where you can hear from others who have walked this path. Anytime you feel overwhelmed, I want you to know you can reach out, even between sessions. You're taking such a brave first step today. Together, we'll take this one day at a time toward your healing. How does that sound?
It sounds really hard. But... I think I'm ready to try. I don't want to feel like this anymore. Thank you for listening and not judging me. I was so scared to talk about this.

You're so welcome. Acknowledging these struggles is an act of profound courage. I'm honored to be part of your support system. Remember, your worth is not defined by your appearance - you have so many gifts to offer the world just by being yourself. I look forward to walking alongside you as you reconnect with those parts of yourself again. Let's start this next chapter together, okay?
Okay. I think... I think I can do this. Thank you.
You can, and you will. I believe in you. Let's begin.

Thank you both for coming in today. I know it can be challenging to discuss these issues, but your insights are invaluable in helping us understand how to best support IJ. I've reviewed the notes about the concerns with his behavior during transport and at school. Can you tell me more about what you've observed?

It's been so hard to watch him struggle. Every morning, the journey to school is a battle. He gets extremely agitated in the car, covering his ears and shouting, especially when there's a lot of traffic noise. Sometimes he even lashes out aggressively. We feel helpless to calm him.

That must be incredibly stressful for all of you. Sensory sensitivities, especially to noise, are very common in individuals with autism. The unpredictable and overwhelming sensory environment during travel can easily cause distress. Are there any other specific situations or triggers you've noticed lead to these intense reactions?

Personal care routines are another big one. Haircuts, nail trimming, even just taking a shower - he finds them all intolerable. We've tried everything to make it easier but he fights us every step of the way. And at school, they've said he can't handle being in a noisy classroom without becoming greatly agitated and even aggressive.

In the classroom setting, IJ requires almost constant one-on-one support. He's unable to work independently for any real length of time. His attention is very easily pulled by any surrounding sights and sounds. Loud noises, like a classroom of chattering students, seem to particularly overwhelm him to the point of distress and acting out behaviors.

It sounds like IJ's sensory processing differences are significantly impacting his ability to cope with daily life demands, both at home and at school. This level of reactivity must make even basic routines feel overwhelming for him. When he's feeling this stressed and overloaded, how does he typically communicate those feelings?

He doesn't have many words to express himself. It's mostly through physical behaviors - pacing, flapping with objects like towels, making repetitive noises. He uses some picture cards and gestures, but when he's highly distressed, it often comes out as aggression, like hitting. We can see how much he's struggling but feel powerless to help in those moments.

Using behaviors and movement to communicate and cope with overwhelming emotions is very common in children with limited verbal skills. It's his way of expressing and regulating his feelings when words are difficult. You mentioned distractibility as well - what does that look like day-to-day in the classroom?

IJ is extremely attuned to his visual environment. He's constantly scanning the room, watching what everyone is doing. It's very difficult to get and sustain his attention, even one-on-one. During work tasks, he engages in a lot of self-talk and noise-making, which actually seems to help him concentrate. But he's in almost perpetual motion - rocking, tapping, fidgeting. Traditional classroom expectations like sitting still are a huge challenge.

Many individuals with autism have difficulty filtering out sensory input, so they're processing every tiny detail in their surroundings. This can make focusing attention very difficult. The self-talk, noise-making, and movement are likely his attempts to regulate that sensory input and arousal level. How does he manage physical proximity and interaction with others?

Touch and close proximity are really hard for him. He won't stand in line or sit with the group at school. If others get too close, he often lashes out or melts down. It's been a huge barrier to him engaging in any kind of group activities or social interaction. Oddly enough, deep pressure touch actually seems to calm him. Weighted blankets and firm hugs relax him when he's distressed.

Tactile sensitivity and difficulty tolerating social proximity are very common in autism. His nervous system may interpret light touch as threatening, while deep pressure provides calming proprioceptive input. This is really helpful information as we consider strategies and accommodations.

Based on everything you've shared, it's clear that IJ's sensory processing differences are significantly impacting his ability to cope with the sensory and social demands of daily life. His limited communication skills make it even harder for him to express his needs and feelings in those moments of distress. This is understandably leading to a lot of behavioral challenges as he tries to manage his overwhelming emotions and sensations.

There are a number of things we can look at implementing to help IJ feel more regulated and successful across his day. Creating a sensory-friendly environment with accommodations like noise-cancelling headphones and movement breaks will be key. We'll also want to focus on building his coping and communication skills so he has more adaptive ways to express his needs. Visual supports, sensory aids, and alternatives to speech can be really empowering. And of course we'll collaborate closely with his school team to ensure we're all using consistent support strategies.

Most importantly, I want to validate how challenging this has been for your family. Parenting a child with intensive sensory and behavioral needs can be physically and emotionally exhausting. But with targeted supports and a lot of compassion, I believe we can help IJ learn to navigate his world in a way that feels safer and more manageable for all of you. What questions do you have as we begin putting these plans in place? I'm here to support you every step of the way.

Honestly, it's just a relief to feel heard and understood. For so long we've felt like we're barely keeping our heads above water, just reacting to each new crisis. Having a real plan forward, and a team behind us...it means everything. I'm sure we'll have many more questions along the way, but right now, just thank you. We're ready to start this journey to helping our son thrive.
good to hear that

Thank you for taking the time to meet with me today. I know how busy life can get, and I really appreciate you prioritizing this discussion about Mary's progress and the challenges you've been noticing at home. Before we dive in, I want to acknowledge that parenting a child with complex needs is no easy feat. The fact that you're here, actively seeking support and strategies, speaks volumes about your dedication to Mary's well-being.

Thank you, that means a lot. Honestly, we're just feeling really overwhelmed lately. Mary has been through so much medically, with the constant ear infections since infancy and then all the dental issues. But it's the day-to-day behavioral and social challenges that are really wearing us down. We just want to ensure we're doing everything we can to help her thrive, you know?

Absolutely, I hear you. And I want to reassure you that you're not alone in this journey. Let's break down some of the specific concerns you mentioned. You noted some difficulties with everyday tasks and self-care motivation. Can you paint me a picture of what that looks like at home?

It's like...she struggles so much with basic problem-solving and understanding that her actions have consequences. Getting her to initiate any kind of self-care routine is a battle. Brushing teeth, getting dressed, even just transitioning between activities - it all requires so much prompting and supervision from us. We've also noticed some unusual physical behaviors, like walking on her toes constantly and sitting in that 'W' position on the floor. And she's just so rigid, you know? Even tiny changes to her routine can completely throw her off and lead to meltdowns.

It sounds like the cognitive inflexibility and difficulties with executive functioning skills like initiation, planning, and problem-solving are really impacting her ability to navigate daily living skills independently. Those are very common challenges for children with developmental disabilities. The toe-walking and 'W' sitting you described are also quite common, and can be related to sensory seeking behaviors or muscle tone differences. We can definitely incorporate strategies to address those areas in our treatment plan. How about Mary's social communication skills? What do you notice in her interactions with others?

That's a huge area of concern for us. She very rarely initiates any kind of conversation or social interaction unless she wants or needs something specific. And when she does communicate, it's often just echoing phrases she's heard from others, even if they don't quite fit the context. She has a really hard time picking up on social cues and unspoken rules in interactions. So she might copy a behavior she saw another child doing, but not understand why it was inappropriate in that setting. Getting information from her is like pulling teeth - we have to keep asking question after question to get any kind of response.

Difficulty with social reciprocity, nonverbal communication, and picking up on contextual cues are key challenges for many children on the autism spectrum. Echolalia, or repeating phrases she's heard, is a very common way for kids with language delays to participate in interactions when they're not sure what else to say. Building up those conversation skills and helping her understand the hidden curriculum of social norms will be an important part of our work together. In terms of following directions and emotional regulation, what are you seeing at home?

Following multi-step directions is really tough for her. We often have to break it down into single, explicit steps and repeat them several times. Even then, she frequently gets distracted partway through a task and completely loses track of what she was supposed to be doing. Emotional regulation is a struggle too, especially when it comes to managing excitement. When she's really happy or excited, it's like she just can't contain it - lots of shrieking, jumping around, sometimes even knocking into things or people. It's gotten to the point where we feel nervous taking her certain places because we're not sure she'll be able to handle the stimulation without melting down.

Difficulties with working memory, attention, and impulse control can absolutely make following directions and regulating big emotions feel overwhelming for kids like Mary. We often see that combination of cognitive and emotional regulation challenges in children with ADHD and autism. It's important to remember that it's not a lack of trying or 'being bad' - her brain is just wired a little differently in how it processes information and sensory input. The strategies we're working on in therapy, like visual schedules, breaking down tasks, and using sensory tools, can help provide the structure and support she needs to feel more successful. On that note, I'm curious if you've noticed any positive changes since Mary started treatment, even small ones.

Actually, yes, now that you mention it. She does seem to be initiating more conversations lately, and offering up information or comments without us always prompting. And while the excitement levels can still get pretty intense, we have seen a bit of improvement in her ability to reign it in when we give her those concrete coping strategies to use. I guess we've been so focused on the challenges that it's easy to overlook the progress, you know?

That's so common, and so understandable. When you're in the thick of these daily challenges, it can be hard to step back and see the bigger picture sometimes. But those small, incremental changes are so important, and I'm really glad to hear you're starting to see some positive outcomes from all the hard work you and Mary are putting in. Change is always a slow, non-linear process, and there will be setbacks along the way - but I want you to hold onto those glimmers of progress as signs of what's possible. You're doing a remarkable job advocating for Mary and ensuring she gets the support she needs. Remember, my role is to be your partner and resource every step of the way. What other questions or concerns are on your mind as we continue this journey together?

Honestly, it's just a relief to have a space to talk through all of this and feel heard. So often it feels like we're just barely keeping our heads above water, juggling her needs and our own exhaustion. Knowing we have a knowledgeable professional in our corner, who gets it and has tangible strategies to offer...that makes all the difference. I'm sure we'll have plenty more questions as we keep navigating this path, but for now, just thank you. Thank you for validating our concerns and helping us feel less alone in this.

It's my absolute privilege to be part of your support system. You're doing a remarkable job in a role that demands so much of you as a parent and a person. Please never hesitate to reach out, even between sessions, if you need an understanding ear or some on-the-spot problem-solving. Together, we'll keep chipping away at those challenges, celebrating the victories along the way, and ensuring that Mary has all the tools and support she needs to thrive. You're not alone in this anymore. We're a team now, and I'm here for you every step of this journey.

Good morning Mr. Tan, thank you for coming in today. I understand you've been experiencing some difficulties with your sleep recently. Can you tell me more about what you've been noticing and how long this has been going on?

Yes doctor, it's been really tough. For about the last two months, I've been struggling with both falling asleep at night and staying asleep through the night. Even if I go to bed early, it takes me at least an hour of tossing and turning before I can actually drift off. And then I keep waking up during the night. This all started happening after my sister passed away unexpectedly a couple months ago.

I'm so sorry to hear about the loss of your sister. Losing a loved one is one of the most difficult experiences we go through in life, and it's very common for grief to disrupt sleep like this. Had you ever struggled with insomnia or other sleep problems before your sister's passing?

No, not at all. I used to be a great sleeper - I'd fall asleep as soon as my head hit the pillow and sleep straight through the night. After the insomnia started, I saw another doctor who prescribed me a medication called dothiepin, but I had a really hard time with the side effects. It made me so drowsy during the day that I couldn't function, and it gave me this horrible dry mouth feeling constantly. I just couldn't tolerate it.

It's good that you recognized those side effects and decided the medication wasn't working for you. There are a number of different approaches we can try to help improve your sleep. Before we discuss those, I'm wondering what strategies you've been using on your own to try to cope with the insomnia? Sometimes people turn to things that can inadvertently make sleep more difficult.

Well, to be honest, I've started having a few drinks of alcohol before bed most nights. I know it's probably not the best idea, but it does seem to help me fall asleep faster. And then during the day, I'm so exhausted from not sleeping well that I'm drinking tons of coffee to try to stay alert - probably about four cups most days. I realize I'm probably getting into a bad cycle with it all, but I'm just desperate to get some rest and be able to function at work.

I completely understand the temptation to turn to things like alcohol and caffeine when you're suffering with insomnia and daytime fatigue. So many people find themselves in that very same cycle. The tricky thing is that while alcohol may help with falling asleep initially, it actually disrupts your sleep architecture and leads to more nighttime awakenings. And the caffeine so late in the day can make it much harder to wind down and fall asleep at night. So while they may feel helpful in the moment, they can worsen insomnia over time. We can definitely work together to find some alternative strategies that will be more supportive of healthy sleep in the long run. I also noticed in your chart that your wife mentioned some unusual leg movements she's noticed while you're sleeping?

Yeah, she says that sometimes my legs will twitch or jerk while I'm asleep, but I'm never aware of it happening. I don't think I have restless legs when I'm awake or anything like that. To be honest, the leg movements don't bother me that much - I'm much more concerned about the trouble I'm having falling asleep in the first place and all the nighttime waking. That's what's really impacting my quality of life.

That's good context to have, thank you. The leg movements may be something called periodic limb movement disorder, which is very common and often linked to disrupted sleep. It may be worth doing a sleep study to assess for that. But I absolutely hear that the insomnia piece is the most distressing part for you right now. Can you tell me a bit more about how the sleep problems have been impacting your day-to-day life and functioning?

It's been really rough, doctor. Most days I'm absolutely exhausted but I have to drag myself to work anyway. I'm having such a hard time focusing and concentrating because of the constant fatigue. I'm worried my performance is really starting to suffer. The only way I'm getting by is with all the coffee, but then of course I'm jittery and wired by evening, which makes it that much harder to sleep. It feels like a vicious cycle I can't escape. It's really starting to affect my mood and stress levels too. I just want to feel like myself again.

I'm so glad you came in to talk about this. Insomnia and sleep disturbances can impact nearly every aspect of health and well-being, and what you're describing with the daytime effects is very common but nonetheless very difficult to cope with. The good news is there are a number of evidence-based treatments we can try. Cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia is considered the gold standard, and I'd also like to discuss some lifestyle changes and potentially short-term medication options with you. We'll work together closely to find the right approach for you. Getting your sleep back on track will go a long way in starting to get those mood and concentration symptoms under control as well. How does that sound to you as a plan moving forward? What questions do you have for me?

Honestly doctor, I'm just so relieved to be talking to someone who understands and has some concrete ideas on how to help. I was starting to feel really hopeless that I'd ever get a good night's sleep again. I'm very open to whatever you think might help. CBT, lifestyle changes, maybe trying a different medication than last time - I'm willing to give it all my full effort. I know I need to cut back on the alcohol and caffeine too. I have to start making my sleep a priority. I'm sure I'll have more questions as we go along, but for now I'm just grateful to have a plan and some hope. Thank you for listening and for your help, doctor.

It's my pleasure, Mr. Tan. Addressing sleep is one of the most powerful things we can do for both physical and mental health. I have no doubt that with some targeted interventions and your own hard work and dedication, we can get your sleep back on track and have you feeling more like yourself again soon. Let's start by scheduling a follow-up to dive into the CBT piece, and in the meantime, I'll put together some resources on sleep hygiene and stimulus control techniques for you to review. Please don't ever hesitate to reach out if you have questions or concerns between visits. Improving your sleep is going to be a process and I'll be here to support you every step of the way. We're in this together now.
Thank you, doctor. I appreciate it so much. I'll start making those changes and look forward to the follow-up.

Good morning EB, thank you for coming in today. I understand you've been experiencing some concerning symptoms related to your sleep. Can you tell me more about what's been happening and how long you've been dealing with this?

Yes, for about two years now, I've been having these episodes where I wake up but I'm completely paralyzed. I can't move at all, even though I'm fully aware of my surroundings. It started happening after I was in a pretty bad car accident. I've been really scared to tell anyone because I thought they might think I was losing my mind or something.

I'm so glad you found the courage to share this with me. I want to assure you that what you're experiencing is a real medical condition, not a sign of mental illness. You're not crazy, and you're not alone in this. Can you walk me through what a typical episode is like for you?

It's absolutely terrifying. I'll wake up but I can't move a single muscle, not even to open my eyes sometimes. But my mind is completely awake and aware. I often feel like there's a presence in the room with me, like someone is watching me or getting closer to me. I sometimes see shadowy figures or hear footsteps, even though I know rationally that there's no one there. And I feel like there's this weight on my chest and I can't breathe properly, like I'm being smothered.

That sounds like an incredibly frightening experience, especially to go through over and over again. The sensations you're describing - the paralysis, the hallucinations, the chest pressure - are all classic symptoms of sleep paralysis. How frequently would you say these episodes have been happening?

When they first started, it was pretty sporadic, like maybe once a week or even once a month. But recently, especially in the last month, it's gotten so much worse. I'm having multiple episodes every single night now. And it's not just at night anymore - it's started happening during the naps I take during the day too. I'm getting really scared to even try to sleep now because I don't want to keep going through this.

I can only imagine how distressing and disruptive this must be for your daily life and overall well-being. Sleep is so fundamental to both physical and mental health. Tell me a bit more about your typical sleep patterns - how much are you usually sleeping at night? And you mentioned napping during the day as well?

I usually aim for about 6 hours per night, but honestly, the quality of my sleep is really poor these days because I'm constantly anxious about having another episode. I'm so exhausted by the end of the workday that I usually end up crashing for an hour or two when I get home, but even those naps are getting disrupted by the paralysis now. I just can't seem to get any restful sleep anymore.

Poor sleep quality and excessive daytime sleepiness can definitely exacerbate sleep paralysis episodes. It's a vicious cycle - the episodes disturb your sleep, but the lack of good sleep makes the episodes more likely. I know you said the hallucinations and unusual sensations only happen around sleep, but I wanted to clarify - have you ever experienced anything similar during your waking hours, when you're fully alert?

No, it's only ever when I'm in that in-between stage of waking up or falling asleep. During the day I feel completely normal, other than being really tired and struggling to focus because of the constant sleep disruptions. But I never have any hallucinations or feelings of paralysis while I'm fully awake.

That's really helpful information, thank you. What you're describing is consistent with isolated sleep paralysis, as opposed to narcolepsy which would involve more daytime symptoms. I know these episodes started after your car accident - did you suffer any physical injuries or head trauma in that accident?

I had some whiplash and bruising, but no major head injury that I know of. The doctors at the time said everything looked okay. But the sleep problems started pretty much immediately after the accident, so it's always seemed connected in my mind.

Significant stress or trauma can sometimes trigger the onset of sleep paralysis, so it makes sense that you would connect it to the accident. I'd like to do a thorough physical exam and neurological workup to rule out any underlying conditions that could be contributing. But based on everything you've shared, this does sound like a textbook case of recurrent isolated sleep paralysis, which fortunately is very treatable.

The most effective treatment is typically a combination of lifestyle changes, sleep hygiene practices, and in some cases, medication. Things like regulating your sleep schedule, avoiding excessive napping, managing stress, and creating a relaxing bedtime routine can make a big difference. There are also specific techniques you can learn to help break out of the paralysis faster when it happens. I'd like to work with you to develop a comprehensive treatment plan to get your sleep back on track. How does that sound to you?

Honestly, I'm just so relieved to finally be talking about this and to know that it's a real thing with a name and treatment options. I was starting to feel like I was losing my grip on reality. Hearing that there are concrete things I can do to get better...it gives me so much hope. I'm definitely ready to try whatever you recommend. I just want to be able to sleep normally again and not dread going to bed every night.
Good morning, thank you for coming in today. I understand you've been experiencing some concerning symptoms. Can you tell me more about what's been happening?

Doctor, I'm really scared. For the past 20 years, I've been seeing things that I know aren't real. It started with just plants and insects, but now I'm seeing people - monks, nuns, priests, people of all different races. It always happens right as I'm waking up from sleep. I'm terrified that I'm losing my mind.

I'm so sorry you've been dealing with this for so long. I can only imagine how frightening and distressing that must be. You're not losing your mind, and you're not alone. Can you describe these visual experiences in more detail for me? How long do they typically last?

Each episode only lasts maybe 10 to 20 seconds, but they happen almost every single day when I wake up, sometimes multiple times a day if I nap. And lately, they've gotten so much more terrifying. I'm seeing disfigured people with one eye, really fierce and threatening figures. I've even seen my dead relatives beckoning to me, like they're trying to lure me somewhere. I wake up screaming sometimes because it feels so real in the moment.

Those sound like incredibly disturbing and vivid experiences. I want to assure you that having visual hallucinations does not automatically mean you're going insane. There are many potential medical causes that we need to explore. I noticed in your chart that you've been taking propranolol for high blood pressure - how long have you been on that medication?

I've been on propranolol for 40 years now. What's strange is that these visions didn't start until about 20 years after I began the medication. I've mentioned it to other doctors over the years but they always just dismissed it or looked at me like I was crazy. I even went to temples seeking spiritual help because I thought it must be something supernatural. But no one has ever taken it seriously.

I'm taking this very seriously, and I'm glad you trusted me enough to share what you've been going through. Visual hallucinations can sometimes be a side effect of certain medications, including propranolol. The fact that they started after you'd been on the medication for a while is interesting - it could be a cumulative effect over time. When these hallucinations happen, do you experience any confusion or other cognitive symptoms alongside the visual disturbances?

No, that's the thing - I'm always completely aware and oriented during these episodes. I know that what I'm seeing isn't real, even though it looks and feels so vivid in the moment. My family can attest that I'm never confused or out of it, just incredibly frightened by whatever I'm seeing. It's like my mind is playing tricks on me but I'm powerless to stop it.

The fact that your consciousness is preserved during these hallucinations and you maintain insight that they're not real is very reassuring from a diagnostic perspective. It suggests that this is not related to a primary psychiatric disorder or neurodegenerative condition. I suspect the propranolol may be the culprit here, given the timing and the known potential for this rare side effect with long-term use. I'd like to propose a change in your medication regimen - would you be open to trying a different blood pressure medication called atenolol instead?

I'm willing to try anything at this point. These visions have been tormenting me for half my life. I just want them to stop. If you think changing my medication could help, I'm more than open to it. I trust your judgment, doctor.

I appreciate your trust and cooperation. Let's start by tapering you off the propranolol and transitioning you to atenolol over the next few weeks. We'll monitor your blood pressure closely during this process to ensure it remains well-controlled. In the meantime, I'd also like to run a few tests - a neurological exam, an EEG, and some bloodwork - just to rule out any other contributing factors. But I suspect the medication switch alone may resolve these hallucinations. I want you to know that you're not alone in this anymore. We're going to figure this out together and get you the relief you've been seeking for so long.

Thank you, doctor. You have no idea what a relief it is to finally feel heard and validated after all these years. I was starting to lose hope that I'd ever be free of these visions. Just knowing that there's a potential solution...it means everything. I'll do whatever you recommend. I'm just so grateful to have found a doctor who is taking this seriously and actively trying to help me.

Good morning, thank you for coming in today. I know it's not easy to reach out for help, especially in a military context. I want you to know that this is a safe space, and everything we discuss here is confidential. Can you tell me a bit about what's been going on that prompted you to seek support?

Thank you, sir. I've been really struggling to function in my role lately. My heart feels like it's racing all the time, I'm barely sleeping, and I'm constantly on edge, like I'm just waiting for something terrible to happen. It's gotten to the point where it's significantly impacting my ability to perform my duties to the standard that's expected of me.

It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of anxiety and hyperarousal symptoms. That's a heavy burden to carry, especially in a high-stress operational environment. When did you first start noticing these changes in yourself?

It all started a few weeks ago, after a mission that involved a particularly tense and dangerous situation. I can't go into the details, but it was a close call. Ever since then, I just haven't felt like myself. It's like I'm constantly on high alert, always anticipating the worst. I can't seem to calm my body or my mind down no matter what I do. It's exhausting and scary.

Exposure to high-threat situations can absolutely trigger this kind of stress response. Your body and brain are reacting to protect you, but those responses can become prolonged and disruptive. You mentioned it's impacting your functioning - can you tell me more about how you've noticed this affecting your daily duties and your interactions with your unit members?

My concentration is shot, sir. During missions and training exercises, I find my mind wandering or fixating on potential threats. My reaction times are slower, and I'm second-guessing decisions that I would normally make confidently. I'm worried that I'm becoming a liability to my team. They depend on me to have their backs and be fully present, and I feel like I'm letting them down. It's eating me up inside.

It's clear how much your commitment to your duty and your team means to you. The fact that you're here, proactively seeking help to be the best servicemember you can be, speaks volumes. I hear your concerns about not wanting to burden your unit, and I want to reassure you that prioritizing your mental health is a sign of strength, not weakness. Based on what you've shared, I believe you would be an excellent candidate for a brief, intensive cognitive-behavioral therapy program tailored for military personnel. It's designed to equip you with practical skills to regulate your physiological arousal, challenge the thought patterns that fuel anxiety, and build resilience. We would meet for focused sessions over the next few weeks, and you would have daily practice assignments to reinforce the skills. The goal is to get you feeling and functioning better as efficiently as possible so you can return to your regular duties with confidence. How does that sound to you?

That sounds promising, sir. I'm willing to put in the work, whatever it takes. I just want to feel like myself again and be the reliable team member I know I can be. When can we start? And will this treatment impact my ability to deploy or my security clearance at all?

We can begin as early as tomorrow. I'll coordinate with your commanding officer to ensure you have the time and space to dedicate to this program without any negative impact on your career trajectory. Seeking help demonstrates insight and proactive problem-solving - qualities we value in our servicemembers. Let's get you scheduled, and in the meantime, I'll send you some preliminary psychoeducational resources to review. Remember, you're not in this alone. Your psychological fitness is a crucial part of your operational readiness, and it's my mission to support you in that. We'll get through this together.

Thank you, sir. I can't tell you how much I appreciate you taking this seriously and giving me actionable steps to work on. I was nervous about coming in, but I'm leaving feeling hopeful and motivated. I'm ready to tackle this head-on and come out stronger on the other side.

Hi there, thank you for coming in today. I know it can be difficult to reach out for help, and I want to acknowledge the courage it takes to be here. I understand you've been struggling with some distressing symptoms recently. Can you tell me a bit more about what you've been experiencing?

Two weeks ago, I was in a really bad car accident. Ever since then, I just...I don't feel like myself. It's like I'm constantly reliving the crash. I have these vivid nightmares every night. And sometimes, it's like I'm watching myself from outside my body, like I'm not really here. It's terrifying.

That sounds incredibly frightening and disorienting. Trauma can have a profound impact on our sense of safety and our relationship with our own bodies and minds. I'm so sorry you're going through this. Can you share a bit about how these experiences are impacting your day-to-day life?

It's turned my whole world upside down. I can't get in a car anymore - even the thought of driving sends me into a panic. I've been having to take taxis to work, but just being in any vehicle makes my heart race and my palms sweat. I feel so detached, like I'm moving through a fog. And any little thing - a car horn, the sound of tires screeching - it makes me jump out of my skin. It's exhausting.

It's completely understandable that your nervous system is on high alert after such a traumatic experience. Your body and mind are trying to protect you, but those survival responses can be really disruptive and distressing when they persist beyond the initial danger. Have you noticed any changes in your sleep patterns or your ability to manage your usual routines?

Sleep has been nearly impossible. Whenever I do manage to drift off, I'm thrust right back into the accident in my dreams. I wake up drenched in sweat, heart pounding. And during the day, I'm constantly on edge, jumpy, irritable. I'm always scanning my surroundings, like I'm waiting for something terrible to happen any second. I can barely focus at work - my mind just keeps replaying the crash over and over.

Nightmares, hypervigilance, intrusive memories - these are all hallmark symptoms of post-traumatic stress. Your mind is trying to process and make sense of the trauma, but it can feel overwhelming and inescapable. Many people find themselves coping by avoiding any reminders of the traumatic event. Have you found yourself changing your behavior or environment in an attempt to feel safer or avoid triggering those distressing memories?

Absolutely. I've been going way out of my way to avoid driving by the intersection where the accident happened, even if it means being late to work. I can't watch any TV shows or movies that have car chases or crash scenes. Even certain songs on the radio - anything that reminds me of that day, I just can't handle it. I know it's not rational, but I feel like I'm losing my mind.

What you're experiencing is a very normal response to a profoundly abnormal and traumatic event. Avoidance is a common coping mechanism, but as you're noticing, it can start to really limit your life and reinforce that sense of danger. Trauma can also deeply impact our beliefs about ourselves and the world. Have you noticed any shifts in how you think about yourself or your surroundings since the accident?

It's like my whole worldview has been shattered. I used to be this confident, independent person. Now, I feel vulnerable and scared all the time, like the world is this dangerous, unpredictable place. Sometimes I even question what's real - I'll have these moments where everything feels dreamlike, hazy. And I can't stop thinking about all the 'what ifs' - what if I had left the house five minutes later, or taken a different route? It's like I'm trying to rewrite reality in my head, but I can't.

That sense of shattered assumptions and the struggle to reconcile the trauma with your understanding of the world is a core part of post-traumatic stress. It's normal to fixate on those 'what ifs' and to feel like your safety and control have been ripped away. But I want you to know that healing is possible. There are evidence-based treatments, like cognitive processing therapy and EMDR, that can help you work through the trauma and reclaim your sense of safety and wholeness. It's a gradual process, but you don't have to navigate this alone. How would you feel about exploring some of those treatment options together?

I'm honestly just so relieved to hear that what I'm experiencing has a name, that it's a real thing and not just me losing my mind. I was so scared that I was broken beyond repair. Knowing that there are actual treatments, that people can recover from this...it gives me hope for the first time in weeks. I'm ready to do the work, to face this head-on instead of just surviving day to day. I want my life back.

I'm so glad you're feeling a glimmer of hope. That's the first step in the healing journey. PTSD is treatable, and recovery is absolutely possible with the right support and interventions. It will take time, and there may be challenges along the way, but I'll be here to guide and support you at every step. You're not broken, and you're not alone in this. Together, we'll help you process this trauma, build coping skills, and gradually reclaim your sense of safety and control. It's going to take courage and hard work, but I have every faith in your resilience and your ability to heal. You've already taken the bravest step by reaching out. I'm honored to walk this path with you. Let's start mapping out a treatment plan and take this one day, one step at a time. Healing is on the horizon - I promise you that.
cool
Thank you for coming in today and sharing your experience with me. I want you to know that you're in a safe space, and I'm here to listen carefully and understand what you've been going through.
I appreciate that. To be honest, I'm not sure where to begin. These nightmares have been consuming my life for about a year now.
Take your time. Would you be comfortable telling me more about these nightmares? What makes them particularly distressing for you?
They always happen in the first few hours of sleep. I wake up feeling absolutely terrified - heart racing, drenched in sweat. It's like I'm trapped in these vivid scenarios that feel incredibly real.
It's heartbreaking to watch. He often wakes up screaming, but when I try to comfort him, he seems completely disoriented.
Could you help me understand the content of these nightmares? What typically happens in them?

I read a lot of crime novels before bed. In these nightmares, I'm always seeing a criminal pursuing my wife. I desperately want to protect her, but I'm completely paralyzed. Sometimes I wake up feeling like I've been in an actual physical struggle.

It sounds like these nightmares are deeply connected to your profound concern for your wife's well-being. You mentioned she's been dealing with serious health challenges. Would you be willing to share a bit more about how her health has been impacting you?

Her health has been a constant source of worry for the past five years. When her condition relapsed after a period of successful treatment, something inside me just... broke. I've been in this perpetual state of anxiety, always anticipating the worst.

Your nightmares seem to be a manifestation of the immense emotional burden you're carrying. It's clear you love your wife deeply and the fear of losing her is overwhelming. What concerns you most about these sleep disturbances?

I'm most worried about two things. First, I can't sleep properly anymore, which is affecting my own health. And second, I'm disrupting my wife's rest when she needs peace and recovery the most. The guilt is consuming me.
Good morning, thank you for coming in today. I understand you've been experiencing some concerning symptoms during your sleep. Can you tell me a bit more about what brought you to our clinic?
For the past few months, I've been screaming in my sleep almost every single night. It's really frightening for me and my family. They're the ones who urged me to get help because they're so worried.

That sounds very distressing for everyone involved. Sleep disruptions can have a profound impact on both the individual and their loved ones. Before we dive into the details of these screaming episodes, I'm wondering if you've experienced any other sleep-related issues prior to this?

Actually, yes. I've been dealing with sleep paralysis pretty frequently since I was about 13 years old. It's terrifying - I wake up unable to move, sometimes with a sense of a presence in the room. When I was younger, I also used to experience muscle weakness when I laughed, but that particular symptom faded after a few years. The sleep paralysis, though, that's been a constant into my adult life.

Thank you for sharing that history. Sleep paralysis can indeed be a very frightening experience, and it's often associated with other sleep disorders. The muscle weakness with laughter you described sounds like cataplexy, which is a symptom sometimes seen in narcolepsy. We'll certainly explore that further. For now, let's focus on these nighttime screaming episodes. Can you walk me through what typically happens during one of these events, to the best of your knowledge?

From what my family has told me, I'll suddenly start screaming as if I'm terrified, but there are no actual words, just these visceral fear vocalizations. This can go on for a few minutes before I seem to settle and fall back into sleep. Sometimes they try to wake me during an episode, and when they do, I often remember having nightmares. A few times, I've woken into a state of sleep paralysis, which is just layers of terror. I never remember the screaming itself, only the nightmares and paralysis if I'm woken up.

That combination of symptoms - the screaming, the nightmares, the sleep paralysis upon waking - is highly suggestive of a condition called REM sleep behavior disorder, or RBD. In RBD, the normal muscle paralysis that occurs during REM sleep is disrupted, allowing the individual to physically act out their dreams, often with vocalizations or movements. Have you noticed any patterns to when these episodes occur throughout the night? And do you recall if you're moving around during them, or mostly still?

My wife has noticed that they seem to happen more in the early part of the night, within the first few hours after I've fallen asleep. She's also observed that I'm generally not thrashing around or anything - my body seems to stay fairly still, it's just the screaming that erupts. We haven't been able to identify any clear triggers - it seems to happen without any obvious prompting or stressors during the day.

The timing and the lack of significant movement also fit the profile of RBD. In many cases, RBD episodes occur more in the later half of the sleep period, when REM periods are longer and more frequent. The vocalizations without much motor activity are also common. To help me get a fuller picture of your sleep patterns, could you describe your typical sleep schedule for me? What times do you usually go to bed and wake up on weekdays versus weekends?

My sleep schedule is probably not the best, to be honest. On weekdays, I'm usually up late working or unwinding, so I don't get to bed until around 1 AM. Then my alarm goes off at 6 AM for work. On weekends, without the work pressure, I tend to stay up even later, usually until 2 or 3 AM, and then sleep in until 8 or 9 AM. I know I should probably be more consistent, but it's hard to break the habit.

You're certainly not alone in struggling with maintaining a regular sleep schedule, especially in our modern world with so many demands and distractions. However, you're right that consistency is key for sleep health. Irregular sleep times can actually worsen sleep disorders like RBD and narcolepsy. Based on everything you've shared, I suspect you may be dealing with RBD, possibly related to an underlying narcolepsy disorder given your history of cataplexy and sleep paralysis. I'd like to schedule you for an overnight sleep study so we can get a clear picture of your brain activity and body movements during sleep. This will help us make a definitive diagnosis and develop a tailored treatment plan. How do you feel about that?

Honestly, it's a relief to feel like there might be an explanation for what's been happening. I've been so scared and ashamed of these episodes, thinking I was losing my mind. Knowing that it's a real sleep disorder, something that can be diagnosed and treated...that gives me hope. I'm absolutely willing to do the sleep study and whatever else you recommend. I just want to get to the bottom of this and find a way to manage it. I'm tired of living in fear of my own sleep.

I completely understand that feeling of fear and frustration. Sleep is meant to be a refuge, a place of rest and rejuvenation, not a source of terror. I want to assure you that you're not alone in this, and there are effective treatments available once we have a clear diagnosis. RBD can be managed with a combination of lifestyle changes, safety precautions, and in some cases, medications. Narcolepsy, if that does turn out to be an underlying factor, also has targeted therapies that can greatly improve symptoms and quality of life. We're going to get to the bottom of this together and develop a plan to get you sleeping peacefully and safely again. Let's get that sleep study scheduled, and in the meantime, I'll give you some resources on sleep hygiene and relaxation techniques to start implementing at home. Remember, you've taken the bravest step by reaching out for help. Better sleep is on the horizon - I promise you that.
yeah good

Good morning, I’m glad you reached out. I understand there are some concerns about substance use and related health issues. Could you share with me what's been happening that brought you to the clinic?

Doctor, I'm so worried about my son. For the past three years, he's been sniffing rubber-based glue using a handkerchief. And now, in the last six months, he's started drinking alcohol as well. His whole behavior and personality have changed, and he's having trouble with basic functions like walking and seeing. I'm scared for his health and safety.

I can hear the deep concern and love in your voice. Substance abuse can indeed have profound effects on an individual's physical and mental health, as well as their relationships and daily functioning. Let's see if we can get a clearer picture of what's been going on. Can you tell me how this pattern of substance use first started?

(visibly agitated and showing signs of withdrawal) It began with the glue sniffing. At first, I was using maybe 5ml a day, but now it's more like 20ml. The drinking started about six months after the glue, when I started hanging out with some older kids who always had alcohol. Now I use them both every day, and I can't seem to stop.

Thank you for sharing that, I know it's not easy to talk about. It's very common for substance use to escalate over time as tolerance develops, and for multiple substances to be used together. This can significantly increase the risks and harms. When you use the glue and alcohol, what kind of effects do you experience?

The glue makes my ears ring and my speech slurred. I get really dizzy and uncoordinated. With the alcohol, I mostly just feel sick and drowsy. But when I combine them, it's like I completely lose touch with reality. I get utterly confused, can't walk straight, it's like the ground is shifting under me. But I also feel this rush, this escape, that I crave.

His personality is unrecognizable now. He's become so aggressive and violent, getting into physical fights. He steals money from us to buy these substances. He's dropped out of school entirely. And like he said, his senses - his sight, his hearing - they seem to be deteriorating. I feel like I'm losing my child in front of my eyes.

The changes you're describing - the anger, the legal and academic troubles, the sensory and neurological symptoms - these are all tragically common consequences of prolonged inhalant and alcohol abuse, especially in developing adolescent brains and bodies. The glue sniffing in particular can cause serious and sometimes irreversible damage to the brain, lungs, liver, and other organs. Have you ever tried to stop using these substances? If so, what was that experience like?

I've tried to quit a few times, but it's been hell. When I stop, I get so angry, so aggressive. I can't sleep at all. My speech gets even more messed up and my hearing goes all fuzzy. The cravings are so bad, I feel like I'm going to die if I don't use. I always end up relapsing and using even more than before. I feel like I'm trapped, like there's no way out of this cycle. (begins to tear up)

(offering a tissue) Those withdrawal symptoms you're describing - the insomnia, the aggression, the intensified speech and hearing problems - they're a clear sign of the profound physical dependence that's developed. And that feeling of being trapped, of the addiction being inescapable - that's the disease talking. But I want you to hear this: recovery is possible. There is hope. With comprehensive treatment - medical detox, counseling, support groups, lifestyle changes - people reclaim their lives from addiction every single day. It's not easy, but it is possible, and you don't have to do it alone. We're here to help you every step of the way.

(tearfully) Thank you, doctor. I was beginning to lose hope that my son could find his way back from this. Hearing that there's a path forward, that we can get him the help he needs...it means everything. We'll do whatever it takes to support his recovery. I just want my child back.

(shakily) I...I want to get better. I'm scared, but I'm more scared of what will happen if I don't stop. I don't want to keep hurting myself and my family. I'm ready to try, to do the work. I just...I can't do it alone. I need help.

Asking for help is an incredible act of courage and the first critical step on the journey of recovery. You're showing immense strength and insight by being here today, by being willing to face this disease head-on. We're going to walk beside you every step of the way. The road ahead may be challenging, but you have the power within you to reclaim your health and your life. Let's start by developing a comprehensive treatment plan, beginning with a safe, medically-supervised detox process to help you through those initial withdrawal symptoms. From there, we'll connect you with intensive counseling, support groups, and any other resources you need to build a strong foundation for long-term recovery. This is a turning point. A new chapter is beginning. And you have an entire team in your corner, cheering you on and supporting you. Together, we'll get you through this, one day at a time.

Good morning, I’m glad you reached out. I understand there have been some concerns raised about your well-being and functioning. Can you tell me a bit about what's been going on from your perspective?

If I may, doctor, we've observed some worrying changes in this soldier's behavior since he joined our unit. He seems to keep to himself most of the time, we've noticed him talking to himself on several occasions, and he appears to be having significant trouble sleeping, based on his fatigue levels during the day.

Thank you for bringing those observations to our attention, officer. Sleep disturbances, social withdrawal, and apparent self-talk can indeed be signs of underlying mental health issues. Let's see if we can get a clearer picture of what might be contributing to these changes. Sir, can you tell me about your history with alcohol? Have you consumed alcohol regularly at any point in your life?

Yes, I have a long history with alcohol. It started back in 1984, when I was serving in the Para Unit. At that time, I was drinking about 360ml of rum per day. After I retired in 2004, my consumption increased to about 600ml of country liquor daily.

That's a significant amount of alcohol over a prolonged period. Chronic heavy alcohol use can have serious impacts on physical and mental health. Have you ever experienced any unusual sensations or perceptions, like hearing voices or seeing things that others might not?

Actually, yes. Around 2005, I started hearing voices of my family members, even when I was completely alone. They would say abusive and threatening things to me. I also started seeing faces of people I used to know, but they would change shape and size in disturbing ways. Sometimes I even feel sensations of someone touching my body, even though no one is there.

Those experiences sound very distressing. Auditory and visual hallucinations, as well as tactile sensations, can be symptoms of a psychotic disorder, which can sometimes be triggered or exacerbated by heavy alcohol use. How did you respond to these experiences when they first started happening? Did you seek any help or support?

At first, I would try to talk back to the voices, but over time, I learned to just try to ignore them as much as I could. I started drinking even more heavily as a way to cope with how distressing and disruptive these experiences were. My family did try to get me some treatment at one point, but it didn't seem to help much, so I gave up on it.

It's very common for individuals to self-medicate with substances like alcohol when dealing with untreated mental health symptoms. However, as you've experienced, while alcohol may provide temporary relief, it often ends up making those symptoms worse in the long run. Can you share how these continued experiences and your alcohol use have impacted your daily functioning and ability to carry out your duties?

It's been very difficult to function properly. My ability to do my job has suffered significantly. I've also struggled to take care of myself - my hygiene, my living space, everything really. I get irritable at the slightest provocations. Even after joining DSC, I continued drinking about 120ml of rum daily. And the hallucinations and strange sensations, they've never really stopped, no matter what I do.

The persistent nature of your symptoms and the significant impact on your functioning suggest that you may be dealing with a serious mental health condition, possibly a psychotic disorder like schizophrenia, along with an alcohol use disorder. These conditions often co-occur and can exacerbate each other. But I want you to know that with proper treatment, it is possible to manage these symptoms and improve your quality of life.

I'd like to start by conducting a thorough psychiatric evaluation to clarify your diagnosis and develop a comprehensive treatment plan. This will likely involve a combination of medications to help with the psychotic symptoms and any underlying mood or anxiety issues, as well as therapy to develop coping strategies and process the impact of your experiences. We'll also need to address your alcohol use, as continuing to drink will make it very difficult for you to achieve and maintain stability. I know this is a lot to take in. What questions or concerns do you have as we begin this process?

I'm just relieved to finally be talking about all of this. I've been struggling for so long, and I was starting to lose hope that I could ever feel better. I know quitting drinking will be hard, but I'm willing to try. I just want to be able to function again, to do my job and live my life without constantly battling my own mind. What kind of treatment will I need to do? How long will it take to start seeing improvements?

Taking the step to seek help is a sign of immense courage and strength. Recovery is a journey, and it will take time and effort, but you've already taken the most important step by being here today. After our evaluation, we'll likely start with a psychiatric medication regimen - antipsychotics to help with the hallucinations and delusions, possibly coupled with antidepressants or anti-anxiety medications if needed. You'll also begin regular therapy sessions to process your experiences and learn strategies to cope with symptoms. For your alcohol use, we'll develop a plan for detox and ongoing substance abuse treatment. It's important to remember that recovery is not always linear - there may be setbacks and challenges along the way. But with commitment and support, significant improvement is absolutely possible. Our team will be with you every step of the way. You don't have to face this alone anymore.
Hello, I’m glad you reached out. How are you feeling today?
I'm feeling wonderful! The world is full of miracles.

Names are just earthly attachments. You can call me whatever you like.

I understand you've been referred by both an ophthalmologist and neurologist. Could you tell me what's been troubling you?

For the past two years, I've been seeing everything with a blackish discoloration. It started in my left eye but spread to both. And for about a year and a half now, everything around me feels unreal, like I'm in a dream.
Can you describe this feeling of unreality in more detail?

Even familiar places and people don't feel real anymore. I find myself touching cold or hot objects, smelling things, even pinching myself to check if I'm dreaming. But it's not about feeling unreal myself - it's everything around me that feels strange.
Have you experienced anything like this before?
Yes, about five years ago, I had brief episodes lasting a few hours or days, but they would go away after sleeping. They weren't as severe or persistent as what I'm experiencing now.
How do these experiences affect your daily life?

Sometimes I get extremely distressed - I cry, want to scream, pull my hair. But I keep doing my routine activities because staying busy actually helps reduce the distress temporarily. It gets worse when I'm stressed, like when I had the flu three months ago.
Have you noticed any other symptoms or experiences?

The visual disturbances are constant, regardless of time or place. My vision itself is fine - I can see clearly, no headaches or double vision. But this blackish tint and feeling of unreality is always there. I've been terrified of losing my vision.

No trauma, no substances. No head injuries or seizures either. I've had multiple tests done - brain MRI, eye exams, blood work - everything's normal. That's what makes this so frustrating.

Evenings are usually the worst for me. Though like I said, if something positive happens, I'll feel a boost for a bit. But it's always temporary and I slide back down.

I understand. Living with untreated depression can feel like being on a roller coaster you can't get off of. But there is hope and help available. Based on what you've shared, I believe you could really benefit from a combination of medication, therapy, and lifestyle changes. How do you feel about exploring some treatment options together?
I'm ready to try anything to stop feeling this way. I know I can't keep living like this. I want to feel better and more stable.

I'm so glad you feel ready to start treatment - that's a huge and brave first step. We'll work as a team to find the best approach for you. Let's start by discussing some medication options and coping strategies you can practice. With commitment and support, you can overcome this and restore your quality of life. You don't have to suffer alone anymore.
I'd like to understand more about your mood and how it impacts your life day-to-day. Can you share what you've been experiencing?

I've been dealing with depression since I was a teenager. I feel down most of the time, but occasionally if something positive happens, I'll feel a bit better for a short time. It never lasts though. My sister has bipolar disorder and I know it runs in my family, so I'm worried.

Thank you for sharing that. Having a family history can increase risk, but it doesn't mean you will definitely develop bipolar disorder. Many factors influence that. I'm wondering, what kind of physical symptoms do you notice with your depression?

I sleep excessively, like 10-12 hours a day, but still feel completely drained. My limbs constantly feel heavy, like I'm weighed down. I've also put on a lot of weight because I can't control my eating, especially craving carbs.

Those are hallmark symptoms of atypical depression. The exhaustion and weight gain can be so frustrating, I understand. Altered sleep and appetite are common. How are your relationships and social interactions affected?

I'm hypersensitive to any perceived rejection. Even mild criticism feels crushing. I get severe anxiety and panic attacks in social settings, so I avoid them as much as possible. It's cost me several jobs. I feel like I can't function.

I hear how much you're struggling and I'm so sorry you're going through this. Social anxiety and interpersonal sensitivity frequently co-occur with atypical depression. Have there been any times you felt an elevated mood or extra energy, even if brief?
Yes, I do get short phases of a few days where I feel more energetic and confident. But they're pretty mild and go away quickly. Not as severe as what my sister goes through.
That's good information to have. I know this is difficult to discuss, but I do need to ask - have you been having any suicidal thoughts? It's crucial I know so I can assess your safety.

Yeah, I do get suicidal thoughts, especially when I feel very rejected or alone. When the depression and anxiety get really intense, it feels unbearable. I've never actually attempted, but I think about it a lot.

I'm so glad you told me. I know that was hard to share. Having frequent suicidal thoughts is serious and we need to get you help to ensure your safety. Based on everything you've described, I suspect you may have atypical depression, possibly with some mild hypomania. But I don't see full bipolar disorder currently.

I'd like to start you on an antidepressant and a medication for your anxiety. I also highly recommend beginning psychotherapy to work on coping skills and address the suicidal thoughts. We'll monitor you closely. You don't have to white-knuckle through this anymore. There is hope and treatment works. Let's get you feeling better.
I'm so glad you made the time to come in and talk today. I'm here to listen and support you. What's been on your mind that you wanted to discuss?

Well, for most of the year, I feel great - I'm outgoing, I keep busy, and I really enjoy life. But like clockwork, every January, it's like a switch flips inside me. I feel like a totally different person.
That has to be so disorienting and upsetting to go through such a dramatic change each year. When did you first start noticing this pattern happening?

I remember it starting when I was 16 and working in hospitality over the Christmas season. I was so busy and social during the holidays, but as soon as they ended, I just crashed. It felt like my mind and body wanted to shut down and hibernate. I assumed everyone felt that way for years.

I can only imagine how confusing and lonely that must have been to go through that on your own for so long. Can you share more about how those winter periods affect you, both physically and emotionally? I want to understand what it's really like for you.

It's an absolute exhaustion that seeps into every part of me - mind, body, and soul. It hits me out of nowhere. I end up canceling all my plans and isolating myself. Even the idea of planning a fun trip or something to look forward to feels totally overwhelming, like I'm in a dense mental fog.

I'm so sorry you've had to struggle with this for so long. That level of fatigue has to be truly debilitating. Was there a moment when you realized this might be more than just the typical 'winter blues'? That it could be Seasonal Affective Disorder?

About eight years ago, a close friend was describing her husband's experience with SAD, and it was like she was narrating my own life story. Suddenly everything clicked - this wasn't just something everyone deals with. There was a name for it.

What a validating moment that must have been to finally feel seen and understood after years of privately battling this. How did that realization impact how you approach and manage these difficult winter periods?

It's made a world of difference. I'm much more proactive now. I start taking vitamin D, I push myself to maintain some social connections even when I don't feel like it - like meeting a friend for coffee. I try to focus on the small signs that spring is around the corner and remind myself this is temporary.

Those are really wise, self-compassionate strategies. You mentioned you're a mother as well - how has living with SAD impacted your parenting and your relationship with your daughter? I imagine that adds a whole other layer to navigate.

Being a mother is honestly my biggest motivator to stay on top of managing my SAD. I've realized that when I withdraw and isolate myself, I'm also isolating her. I want to model healthy coping skills for her, so I make the extra effort to stay present and engaged with her, even when I'm struggling. It's not always easy though.

What incredible self-awareness and strength. I hope you can be proud of the hard work you're putting in, both for yourself and your family. Of all your coping tools, which have you found to be the most effective for getting you through the hardest days?

Scheduling little treats or things to look forward to seems to help, like a nice dinner or a movie night with my daughter. Staying connected to my friends and forcing myself to socialize a bit. And constantly reminding myself that these feelings are temporary, that spring always returns. Reframing it like a storm I have to weather.

I'm so glad you've found some strategies that help you ride out the waves. I'm curious, have you been able to identify any specific triggers that tend to intensify your symptoms, in addition to the seasonal pattern?

The jarring shift after the Christmas season is always particularly brutal - going from an adrenaline rush of busyness to a sudden halt. It was especially bad the winter after my daughter was born, I suspect because of the added stress and life changes of new motherhood piling on.

That makes so much sense. The post-holiday crash combined with postpartum adjustment sounds like a perfect storm. Please know that you don't have to muscle through this alone anymore. I'm here to support you, and together we can add even more tools to your SAD-fighting toolkit. You're doing a great job already, and I believe you'll only get better at this with time. Be patient with yourself. Healing is a process.
Welcome. I appreciate you being here today. Would you like to share what motivated you to seek support?
Every winter, I feel like a completely different person. It usually starts around October and continues until spring. I just can't seem to function normally.
That sounds really challenging to go through such significant changes every year. Could you help me understand more about how these winter months affect you?

I sleep much more than usual, sometimes 12 hours a day, but still wake up exhausted. I crave carbs constantly and have gained weight. The worst part is feeling so hopeless and disconnected from everyone.
It must be really difficult dealing with these overwhelming changes in your sleep, eating patterns, and emotions. When you say you feel disconnected, could you tell me more about that?
I just withdraw from everything. My friends eventually stop calling because I always say no. I feel guilty about it, but I can't help it.
I hear how much this isolation affects you, and the guilt that comes with it. You mentioned feeling different in other seasons - could you tell me about that?
That's what's so frustrating - I'm a completely different person in summer. I'm energetic, social, productive. Then winter comes, and it's like someone turns off the lights in my brain.
That contrast must feel really destabilizing. You've described this powerful image of lights being turned off in your brain. How does this affect your daily life?
It's a struggle to get to work on time because I can't get out of bed. I've started working from home more. I cancel plans with friends. Even simple tasks like grocery shopping feel overwhelming.
It sounds like you're carrying a heavy burden, trying to maintain your daily responsibilities while struggling with these symptoms. What time of day do you find most challenging?
Mornings are brutal. The darkness makes it impossible to get started. By afternoon I function a bit better, but then it gets dark so early, and I just want to go back to bed.
Thank you for sharing that pattern with me. It helps me understand what you're going through. Have you found anything that provides even a small amount of relief during these times?
I've tried vitamin D supplements, but I'm not consistent. I bought a light box but haven't used it much. It's hard to maintain any routine when I feel this way.

It makes sense that maintaining routines feels challenging when you're struggling with these symptoms. Would you be interested in exploring some strategies together that might feel manageable for you?
Yes, I would. I'm tired of losing months of my life every year to this. I need something to change.

I hear your determination to make changes, and I'm here to support you in that. Let's work together to understand your patterns better and develop approaches that feel sustainable for you. What would you like to focus on first?
Hello. Thank you for coming in today. I'd like to understand what brought you to the hospital and how we can best support you during this difficult time.

I've lost so much weight and have absolutely no appetite. I'm certain I have cancer that the doctors are missing. I've seen three gastroenterologists already, but I don't trust their tests. I keep getting worse and no one seems to take it seriously.

I hear how frightening and frustrating this must be for you, especially when you feel your concerns aren't being heard. I understand you've recently lost your husband. Can you tell me how you've been coping with that loss?

Yes, John passed away three months ago, but that's not why I'm feeling this way. These physical symptoms - they must be cancer. I've read about so many cases where doctors missed diagnoses. I have no other reason to be depressed. We had a good life together.

It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of uncertainty and worry right now. While we take your physical symptoms very seriously, I'd like to understand more about your daily life. How have your sleep and energy levels been?

I have no energy at all, and I've lost all interest in everything - even my grandchildren's visits. But it's because of this illness they're missing. Why won't anyone believe me about the cancer? I know my body, something is very wrong.

I want you to know that I believe you are experiencing real symptoms that are causing you significant distress. Your concerns matter. Given everything you're going through, I need to ask - have you had any thoughts of harming yourself?

No, I just want someone to find what's wrong with me. I'm tired of doctors dismissing my concerns. I've been keeping a journal of all my symptoms, writing down everything I experience. I barely sleep because I'm so worried.
Thank you for being so open with me. You've been on sertraline for two weeks now. I'd like to hear how you've been feeling since starting the medication, both emotionally and physically.

My mood is somewhat better, maybe 50% improved. I can get out of bed now at least. But I still have these physical symptoms - now nausea and constipation. I need to see another specialist. These symptoms keep changing and that must mean something.

I'm glad to hear your mood has improved somewhat. The nausea and constipation you're experiencing might be temporary side effects of the medication. It's important we monitor these symptoms. How has your appetite been recently?

It's a bit better, I've gained about three pounds. My daughter seems relieved about that. But that doesn't mean I don't have cancer. I read about a case where someone had similar symptoms and by the time they found it...

Your health concerns are understandable, and it's good that you're paying attention to your body. Let's work together to monitor both your physical and emotional wellbeing. Would you be willing to discuss some additional ways we might help you feel more supported?
I suppose so. But I still want to understand why I'm having all these physical symptoms. It's hard to focus on anything else when I'm so worried about my health.

I understand this uncertainty is very difficult to live with. Let's work on managing these concerns together, while continuing to monitor your symptoms. Could you tell me more about what a typical day looks like for you now?
Hi Bella, thank you for coming in today. I understand from your mom that you've been having some difficulty managing your anger. I'd really like to hear from you about what's been going on.
Yeah... I get really mad sometimes. Last week I punched my teammate because she touched me when she walked by. I feel bad about it now.
Thank you for sharing that with me. It takes courage to talk about these difficult moments. Could you help me understand what was going through your mind when that happened?
I felt like she was trying to mess with me. I needed to teach her not to put her hands on me. But... maybe I overreacted. I just get this feeling inside that I can't control.
It sounds like these feelings can be really overwhelming for you. I'd like to understand more about this - how often do you find yourself feeling angry or irritable?
Almost all the time. Mom says everyone has to walk on eggshells around me. I get into these moods where I just feel cranky and want to shut down. Sometimes I don't even know why I'm so angry.
That must be really hard, feeling this way so often. Could you tell me more about these 'shut down' moments? What happens when you experience them?

It's like my brain just stops working right. I get really snappy with everyone. Sometimes I won't talk to my teacher for days. And when I have meltdowns, I scream and slam doors. Afterwards, I feel really embarrassed.
I can hear how these experiences are affecting you deeply. Let's try to understand what leads to these moments. What kinds of situations or things tend to trigger these meltdowns?

Sometimes little things, like taking my medicine or someone standing too close. I know it sounds stupid, but I just can't help it. And then I can't move on from being angry. It's like I'm stuck feeling this way.
Those feelings don't sound stupid at all, Bella. They're very real to you, and it's important we understand them. How do these feelings affect your relationships with friends?

People say I'm funny and they like me, but then I get angry and ruin everything. I might get kicked off my sports teams because I keep getting aggressive with my teammates. I don't want to lose my friends.
I hear how much you care about your friendships and how these anger issues are impacting them. What changes would you like to see in how you handle these situations?
I want to stop having these meltdowns. I want to be able to control myself when I get mad. Sometimes I feel like I'm acting like a little kid, but I can't stop. I'm tired of feeling this way.

Thank you for being so honest about what you'd like to change. Your awareness and desire to make things better is really important. Would you like to work together to develop some strategies that might help you manage these feelings?
Yes, please. I don't want to keep hurting people or pushing them away. I just don't know how to stop myself when I get really angry.
I understand, and I'm here to help you learn those skills. We can start by exploring what happens in your body when you begin feeling angry. Would you be willing to talk about that?
Welcome! I'm really glad you're here today. Would you mind sharing your name with me?
Dillon.
