Thank you, Dillon. I've had a chance to talk with your parents about some challenges you've been experiencing at home and school. I'd really like to hear from you about what's been difficult. Would you like to share?
Sometimes I get really mad. I can't help it. Yesterday I knocked over all the books in class because Tommy was sitting too close to me. I didn't want him near me.
That sounds like a really intense moment. When you start feeling mad like that, what do you notice happening in your body? What does it feel like?
I feel hot and my hands get tight. I want everyone to leave me alone but they keep trying to talk to me and make it worse. Sometimes my heart beats really fast too.
Thank you for explaining those feelings so well. It sounds overwhelming when your body feels that way. Do you find yourself experiencing these angry feelings often?
Yeah, most days. Nobody likes me anyway. Even my parents don't love me. When kids play tag, they hit me on purpose just to make me mad. Everyone's always trying to upset me.

It must feel very lonely and frustrating to feel that way. I can hear how much this hurts you. I'd like to understand more about your daily challenges. Could you tell me what happens when you try to do your homework?
I hate homework! I can't sit still and everything's too hard. When Mom tries to help, I just want to throw everything. Nothing makes sense and it makes me so angry!
I can see how difficult and frustrating this is for you. Would you be interested in learning some ways to help yourself feel calmer when these big feelings come up?
I guess. But nothing works. Sometimes I get so mad I break things. I broke my door. I didn't mean to, but I couldn't stop. It's like I lose control.
Those moments when you feel out of control must be really scary. How do you feel afterwards, when these big angry moments pass?
Bad. Sometimes I cry. But then something else makes me mad again and it starts all over. My brain just keeps thinking about things that make me angry. I can't make it stop.
It sounds like these thoughts and feelings can be really overwhelming. If you could change things about school and home, what would you like to be different?
I want to have friends again. Nobody wants to play with me anymore because I get too mad. And I want my parents to take me places again. They don't take me anywhere because I always ruin it.

I hear how much you want things to get better, and how much you miss having those positive experiences with friends and family. Would you like to work together to find ways to help you manage these strong feelings?
Yes. I don't want to be angry all the time anymore. I want things to be different.

I'm really glad you're open to working on this, Dillon. Together, we can explore some strategies to help you feel more in control of your emotions and rebuild those connections with your friends and family. We'll take it one step at a time.
Welcome, I'm glad you're here today. Before we begin, I'd like to create a comfortable space for you to share. What brings you in to see me?

Well, things started changing about a month ago when the days got shorter. I just feel so tired all the time, and I can barely get out of bed. It's like this heavy weight is pressing down on me. I've never felt quite like this before.
That sounds really challenging to experience. I'd like to understand more about your experiences throughout the year. Could you tell me how you typically feel during other seasons?

During summer and spring, I'm a completely different person. I'm energetic, social, productive. But now, I just want to sleep all day. I'm craving carbs constantly and I've gained weight. It's like I'm not even the same person anymore.
That contrast must be really difficult to cope with. I'm hearing significant changes in your energy and daily patterns. How have these changes affected your relationships and daily activities?

I've been canceling plans with friends. Even simple things like grocery shopping feel overwhelming. I know I should go outside, but I just can't motivate myself. I feel guilty about letting everyone down.
It's understandable to feel overwhelmed when experiencing such significant changes. Could you help me understand which parts of the day feel most challenging for you?

Mornings are the worst. It's dark when I wake up, and I feel hopeless. By afternoon I might feel a little better, but then it gets dark so early, and the cycle starts again. It's like I can't escape it.

Thank you for sharing these difficult experiences with me. I can hear how much this is impacting your daily life. Have you found anything that provides even a small amount of relief from these feelings?

I bought a light therapy lamp but haven't been consistent with it. I take vitamin D sometimes. I know I should exercise, but I just don't have the energy. Everything feels like such an enormous effort.
I hear how much you're struggling. Given everything you've shared with me, I need to ask - are you having any thoughts of harming yourself?
No, nothing like that. I just feel... empty. Like I'm waiting for spring to come so I can feel like myself again. I miss feeling normal.

I understand this feeling of emptiness and waiting is really difficult. Would you be interested in exploring some strategies together that might help you cope with these challenges during the darker months?
Yes, I would like that. I can't keep going through winters like this. I need to find a way to manage these feelings better.

I appreciate your openness to working on this together. Let's start by understanding what small, manageable steps might help you feel more like yourself, even during these difficult months. What would feel most helpful to focus on first?
Welcome, it's great to have you here today. I appreciate you taking the time to talk with me. How have you been feeling lately?

Honestly, I've been really frustrated and overwhelmed. I saw this post on Reddit that was basically telling people to shut up about speculating that some celebrity is having a manic episode or psychotic break, just because he's been acting weird after getting relentless hate and antisemitic comments directed at him and his family every single day.

That sounds like a very heavy and upsetting situation. I can understand why seeing those kinds of hateful comments and accusations would be so distressing, especially when they are directed at someone's family and involve such a sensitive topic like antisemitism. How did reading about that situation make you feel?

It just made me so angry that people can be so cruel and clueless. Like, they have no idea what it's like to be in that person's shoes, getting death threats constantly and having your wife and kids dragged into it. And then on top of that, to have people who don't even know you personally throw around armchair diagnoses and act fake concerned about your mental health. It's so messed up.

You're absolutely right, that is an awful position to be in and the way people are responding sounds really invalidating and hurtful. It's completely understandable to feel angry when people make light of something so serious or act like they understand what someone is going through when they couldn't possibly know the full story. I'm hearing how much pain there is in this situation, both for the celebrity being attacked and for you as someone who empathizes with that kind of suffering.

Exactly. And the post talked about how antisemitism is so often downplayed or not taken seriously, even though Jewish people are such a small minority and that kind of hate has such a long and traumatic history. It just makes me sick to see that kind of vitriol go unchecked. I can't imagine having to deal with that day in and day out.

That is truly heartbreaking. Antisemitism and hate speech of any kind should never be tolerated, no matter how small a minority group might be. The idea that anyone should have to endure constant threats and attacks like that is just unacceptable. I'm so sorry that this is bringing up such intense and painful feelings for you. Please know that your anger and hurt are valid. No one should have to feel unsafe or devalued because of their identity.

I really appreciate you saying that. It helps to feel like someone actually gets it and isn't trying to brush it off or look for reasons to blame the person being victimized. I know it's not my situation directly, but it still hits so close to home, you know? It's hard not to put myself in those shoes and just feel that pain and anger so viscerally.

Absolutely, I can only imagine how triggering and personal this must feel for you, especially with your experience growing up closely with the Jewish community and hearing firsthand about the deep generational trauma that continues to this day. Your compassion and ability to empathize so deeply is a gift, even when it's overwhelming to bear witness to such cruelty. I want to remind you to be gentle with yourself as you process these heavy emotions and memories. Your feelings are important and valid.

Thank you, I really needed to hear that. It's helpful to be able to talk through this with someone who actually listens and takes it seriously. I think I just need to focus on what I can control and try to channel this energy into something more positive, like speaking out against hate when I see it or supporting people who are going through hardships. But I also know I need to set boundaries so I don't get completely swallowed up by it.

That sounds like a very wise and compassionate approach. Channeling your empathy into action steps to combat hate and support others can be so empowering. At the same time, I'm glad you recognize the need to set boundaries to protect your own well-being. It's okay to feel these difficult emotions and to take a step back when you need to. I'm here to support you in finding that balance. Remember, your mental health matters, too. Thank you so much for sharing openly with me today. I'm honored to be part of your healing journey.

Hello there! Thank you for taking the time to connect today. It takes courage to reach out for support, and I’m truly glad you did. I’m here to listen and offer a caring, non-judgmental space where you can feel safe sharing whatever is on your mind. How have you been feeling lately? Is there anything in particular that’s been weighing on you that you’d like to talk about?
Not great, to be honest. I've been dealing with a lot of stress and anxiety at work. I had a really tough conversation with my manager a few days ago that has left me feeling pretty shaken up.

I'm so sorry to hear that. Workplace issues can be incredibly stressful, especially when they involve difficult dynamics with managers or colleagues. Can you tell me a bit more about what happened during that conversation?

Well, I've been having problems with a rude and condescending coworker for a while now. But when I brought it up to my manager, he totally sided with my coworker and even threatened to put me on an improvement plan, saying I was on HR's radar. But I checked with another manager and found out that was a complete lie.

Wow, that sounds like a serious breach of trust from your manager. It's understandable that you would feel betrayed and anxious after an exchange like that. Dishonesty from a superior can really undermine your sense of security and stability at work. I'm curious, has your relationship with this manager always been strained?

No, that's the thing - we used to have a pretty positive relationship. But it's like things have changed overnight and now I'm constantly on edge, worrying I'm going to get fired. Especially in this job market. On top of that, my manager denied my vacation request for October, even though I've barely taken any time off this year because of work demands. I'm just feeling really trapped and hopeless.

That's an immense amount of pressure to be under, I can only imagine how exhausting and demoralizing it must feel to have the rug pulled out from under you like that at work. Everyone deserves to feel respected and secure in their job, and to be able to have a healthy work-life balance. It's a big red flag that you're being denied even basic leave privileges after proving your commitment. I'm noticing your language about feeling trapped and hopeless - how has this situation been impacting your mental health?

It's been terrible, to be honest. I've barely slept all week since that conversation. The anxiety and depression have been pretty overwhelming. I'm planning to talk to my doctor about it and try to get documentation for a short-term disability leave. But I'm nervous about how to handle things with work and HR. I'm afraid if I'm too open with HR about my issues with my manager, they might tell him and make things even worse.

I'm glad you're taking steps to prioritize your health and well-being. Lack of sleep can really exacerbate mental health issues, so getting some medical support and time to rest and recover is crucial. I understand your concerns about retaliation if you're transparent with HR, that's a valid fear. I would recommend starting with your doctor's visit first and foremost. Having that documentation and support will be important regardless of what you decide to disclose to your workplace. Once you have a clearer sense of your leave options, then you can assess how much you feel comfortable sharing with HR. You're in a vulnerable position right now and it's okay to put your health and safety first. I know the uncertainty is scary, but we will figure out a plan to get you through this, one step at a time. You don't have to go through this alone.
Welcome, it's good to see you today. I appreciate you making the time to come in and talk. How have things been going for you lately?

Honestly, not great. I've been dealing with a lot of anger and frustration over a job situation that really screwed me over. I've been unemployed for months now because of it and it's taking a huge toll.

I'm so sorry to hear you're going through such a challenging time. Losing a job, especially in a way that feels unfair, can be incredibly destabilizing. Can you tell me more about what happened with this job situation?

So I had been working in hospitality for years but was ready for a change. I interviewed with this company and they made it seem like I had the job - gave me a tour, had me shadow someone, said they'd email me a training schedule. I was so excited that I quit my restaurant job, thinking I was all set. But then...they just ghosted me. No email, no returned calls, nothing. And I had no proof of their offer so I couldn't do anything about it legally.

Wow, that is awful. I can completely understand your anger, that was a massive betrayal of trust on their part. To lead you on like that, let you quit your other job, and then leave you hanging with no communication? Of course you would feel enraged and thrown for a loop. Your feelings are so valid.

I just spiraled from there. It's been 4 months and I still can't find work, despite applying to over 100 jobs. I ran out of savings and can't afford my meds anymore, so my mental health is in the gutter. I feel like I'm back at square one after working so hard to improve my life. I'm trying to tell myself I'll get through this but I'm really struggling not to lose hope.

It sounds like this experience pulled the rug out from under you in a profound way, financially, professionally, and emotionally. Losing access to your medication on top of everything else must feel like a huge setback. I hear how much effort and resilience it's taking for you to keep going and not give up despite these compounded hardships. Your perseverance is admirable. At the same time, I want to hold space for how demoralizing and exhausting this is. Your anger is more than justified. It's okay to not be okay right now.

I think I just need to vent, honestly. I'm so sick of being jerked around, you know? I keep replaying that interview in my head, thinking I should've known better, pushed for something in writing. But I was just so excited for the opportunity. I hate that they took advantage of that. And some people online have been so cruel about it, saying I deserved it for being 'stupid'. As if I asked to be lied to and left in the dust.

It takes a lot of courage to be vulnerable and share your story, especially when you've been burned before. Those cruel messages are so toxic and wrong - you absolutely did not deserve what happened to you, no one does. It's not your fault that you trusted the word of an employer who should have been trustworthy. Hindsight is 20/20, and even if you had gotten the offer in writing, them ghosting you was still completely unethical. You aren't stupid, you're human. Anyone would be excited in your shoes. I'm so sorry people tried to shame you just for looking for support.

I really appreciate your compassion, it means a lot to be heard and validated instead of blamed. You're right, I was in a vulnerable position and they took advantage. I couldn't have predicted that. I'm trying to learn from it without beating myself up, but it's hard. I think I just want to focus on moving forward as best I can, even if it's a slow process. I'm going to keep trying to find work and get my meds sorted out. Not much else I can do.

You're already showing so much insight and grace towards yourself by holding both the lesson and the unfairness of the situation. Moving forward is the goal, but healing is rarely linear. It's okay for it to be hard and slow. You're doing the best you can with a really tough hand. Let's brainstorm some small, actionable steps you can take this week to care for yourself and your needs during the job search. And remember, my door is always open. You have support, even on the hardest days.
Hello there! Thank you for taking the time to connect today. I'm glad you reached out for support. What's been on your mind lately?

I've been struggling a lot with people in my life who refuse to understand or empathize with my mental health issues. I recently had to cut ties with some family friends because of it, and it's brought up a lot of pain.

That sounds really tough. Losing relationships, especially ones that were previously cherished, is always difficult. And when it's due to them invalidating your very real struggles, I imagine that makes it even harder. Can you tell me more about what happened?

This guy, who's good friends with my narcissistic dad, was basically criticizing me for not being as successful as he was at my age. Completely ignoring the fact that I'm dealing with serious mental health problems that he's never experienced. He just believed all the lies my dad told about me, without even trying to hear my side.

Wow, I'm so sorry you were subjected to that judgment and lack of empathy. Having your painful experiences dismissed and being unfairly compared to others is incredibly invalidating. It's especially hurtful when it comes from people you once trusted. I'm wondering, has this kind of attitude been a pattern in your family?

Yeah, sadly it has been, especially with my dad. I actually went no contact with him a couple months ago because of his history of abuse and refusal to take accountability. He's always been a liar and never really cared about my wellbeing. So I guess I shouldn't be surprised his friends are acting the same way. But it still hurts.

I can only imagine how painful it is to not only contend with the challenges of mental illness, but to have your primary caregiver actively undermine and gaslight you in the process. The fact that you've taken the courageous step to protect yourself and go no contact speaks volumes to your resilience. It's completely understandable that extending that boundary to his enabling friends would bring up grief, even if you know it's necessary. Anytime we lose a relationship, it's natural to mourn the connection we wished we could have had, even if the actual dynamic was toxic.

You're right, it is a huge sense of loss, of what could have been if they had been capable of showing up for me in the ways I needed. I know I made the right call to cut ties for my own well-being. But I think I'm also realizing how not alone I am in this. So many other people with mental illness have to deal with ignorant judgment and victim-blaming from even their closest circles.

That's such an important realization. While your pain is unique to your story, the tragedy of mental health stigma, especially in families, is all too common. So many people can relate to having their conditions and efforts belittled, or being held to unfair standards by those who don't understand the enormous impact of mental illness. There's a special kind of gaslighting and guilt that comes with having powerful emotions and experiences constantly denied by those who are supposed to love and validate you. I'm curious if you've been able to find any spaces, in person or online, to connect with others who do get it?

A little bit. I've started opening up to a few friends who also deal with mental health stuff, and some online communities. It helps to not feel so alone and crazy, you know? To see my experiences reflected and know I'm not just making it all up or not trying hard enough. But I think I still have a hard time fully trusting and leaning on that support.

That makes so much sense. When you've had your reality denied for so long by people so close to you, it can be really hard to undo that doubt and know what to believe, even when you're getting validation from healthier sources. It takes time to rebuild that self-trust and open up to new connections, especially when past attempts have gone so painfully wrong. I really admire the risks you're taking to find more affirming relationships and communities. That discernment of who deserves your story is so important. I hope in time, with practice and perhaps with the support of a therapist if you're open to it, you can start to internalize that validation more deeply and consistently. You deserve to be fully seen and supported in your struggles and your strengths. I'm rooting for you and I'm here to remind you as often as you need - you are not alone, you are not broken, and you are so incredibly worthy of empathy and care.

Hello there! Thank you for taking the time to reach out today. I appreciate how much courage it can take to seek support. I want you to know I’m here to listen, and this is a safe space for you to share whatever’s on your mind. How are you feeling right now?
I don't even know. I feel like I'm in a daze. I just found my dad dead last night and I haven't been able to sleep. I can't believe he's really gone.

I can't imagine the shock and grief you must be experiencing. Losing a parent so suddenly is one of the most painful things a person can go through. Please know that whatever you're feeling right now is completely valid and understandable. There's no right or wrong way to grieve.

I keep thinking I'm going to wake up and it will all be a nightmare. He had been so depressed and ill for years but I never thought... I should have checked on him more, I should have done something to prevent this. It's my fault.

I hear the enormous weight of guilt and regret in your words. It's so common to replay those 'what ifs' and 'if onlys' when we lose someone, especially to suicide. The truth is, you couldn't have known this would happen. You did the best you could with the information you had. Blaming yourself, as tempting as it is, doesn't serve your father's memory or your own healing. His death is not your fault.

Logically I know that but I can't help feeling like I failed him. And now I'm terrified I'm going to fall apart. Seeing him like that... it's an image I can never unsee. I don't want to do that to my own loved ones but the pain feels unbearable. I posted about it online, trying to beg people not to make the same choice he did. I don't want anyone to suffer like this.

My heart breaks for the trauma you witnessed and the agony you're in now. It's a pain I wouldn't wish on anyone. I'm struck by the empathy and compassion you're extending to others even in the depths of your own grief. Wanting to spare other families from this anguish is such a powerful light to hold onto right now. At the same time, I want to make space for your own feelings and needs. You deserve the same compassion you're showing to others.

I don't know how to do this. How to live in a world that doesn't have him in it. We had a complicated relationship and so much was unresolved. I thought we'd have more time. I'm so angry at him for leaving me like this but more than anything I just want him back.

The loss of a parent reshapes your entire world, regardless of the nature of your relationship. It's natural to feel angry, lost, and devastated. Grief is messy and complicated, especially grief related to suicide. All of your emotions are welcome here, even the ones that feel contradictory or hard to express. I know it feels impossible to imagine ever feeling okay again. I want to reassure you that healing is possible, even if it doesn't feel that way right now. Healing doesn't mean forgetting your father or erasing your pain. It means learning to carry his memory and your love for him in a way that allows room for the rest of your life, too. I'm here to support you in that process, for as long as you need. You don't have to walk this path alone.

Welcome! I’m really glad you decided to connect with me today. I understand it can feel daunting to start therapy, especially if you’ve had tough experiences before. I appreciate you taking this step and want you to know I’m here to support you. How have you been feeling about beginning this process?

Honestly, I'm feeling pretty discouraged and exhausted by it all. This is my 4th therapist and I'm starting to lose hope that I'll ever find someone who actually helps. My last one kept insisting that my depression is only due to personal problems and that if I could just solve those, I wouldn't need mental health support anymore. But that's not how it feels to me at all.

That sounds incredibly invalidating and demoralizing. Depression is a complex illness that can stem from a variety of factors, including brain chemistry, genetics, trauma, and yes, sometimes situational stressors. But to imply that it's just a matter of willpower or solving external problems is a gross oversimplification. I'm so sorry you weren't given the comprehensive, compassionate care you deserve. It's understandable to feel hopeless after repeatedly opening up and not getting the support you need. I'm curious, what has your experience been with the medical side of treatment, if you don't mind me asking?

I'm on my second type of antidepressant now. I had to switch from the first one due to side effects. But even with the meds, I've been struggling for over 8 months. I know medication alone isn't enough, that's why I keep trying to find a good therapist to do the deeper work. But I'm so tired of pouring my heart out to people who either don't remember what I tell them, just pity me, or act like I'm not trying hard enough to get better.

I can hear how drained and frustrated you are. Managing medications is often a process of trial and error, and even when you find one that helps, it's rarely a complete solution in itself. The fact that you've persisted in seeking therapy to supplement your meds, even after multiple disappointing experiences, speaks volumes to your resilience and determination to heal. I know it doesn't feel like it, but that persistence is incredibly admirable. You deserve so much credit for not giving up on yourself, even when the system has let you down.

I don't feel resilient, I feel pathetic. Like I'm broken and unfixable. I'm fighting with myself just to get out of bed and do basic things. The suicidal thoughts are constant, and it's terrifying. I'm scared I'm going to lose the battle one day and actually kill myself. But I'm even more scared of feeling this way forever. I can't imagine not being depressed anymore, but I also can't fathom living like this for the rest of my life.

I appreciate you sharing those fears with me, I know how vulnerable that is. The severity of your depression and suicidal thoughts must be devastating to contend with every day. I want you to know that while your suffering is very real and valid, the hopelessness you feel is a symptom of your illness, not a reflection of reality. You are not broken or doomed to feel this way forever. Healing is possible, and you are so worthy of feeling better, no matter how long it takes or how many tries it requires to get the right support.

I know putting your trust in yet another therapist is a huge act of courage and faith. I don't take that lightly. If you're willing, I'd like to really take the time to understand your story, your symptoms, and your strengths. I want to work collaboratively with you to find strategies that resonate and make a meaningful difference, even if progress feels slow. This is a marathon, not a sprint, and I'm committed to being in your corner for as long as you'll have me.

I also want to prioritize your safety, given the intrusive suicidal thoughts. Let's make a plan for how to keep you protected during the hardest moments, and identify some coping tools and resources you can lean on between our sessions. Your life is precious, and I'm honored to support you in preserving it.

I want to believe that it's possible to get better. It helps to hear you say that this isn't a moral failing or weakness on my part. I think I've internalized a lot of stigma and judgment from my past experiences. I'm not used to someone expressing so much understanding and patience. It's a relief to feel like maybe I can be honest about how bad things truly are and not be dismissed or told to just try harder.

I know I have a long road ahead of me and that there will probably be a lot more trial and error. But for the first time in a while, I feel a tiny bit of hope that there could be light at the end of this tunnel, that I might not be trapped in this darkness forever. I'm willing to give this an honest shot, even though I'm terrified to get my hopes up again. Thank you for creating a space that feels safe enough to take that risk.

Thank you so much for your bravery and willingness to trust me with your pain and your tentative hopes. I'm incredibly moved by your vulnerability and insight. You're absolutely right, confronting the lies depression tells you and unlearning the judgment you've absorbed is a critical part of the healing process. It's not easy to open yourself up to hope again after hope has been shattered so many times before. But I believe that capacity for hope, as scared as it is, is one of your greatest strengths. It's what's kept you going and brought you here today, still fighting for the care and stability you deserve.

I want to affirm and celebrate every ounce of progress, every courageous step, no matter how small they might seem. The fact that you're willing to bring your full truth into this room, without minimizing or sanitizing the depths of your anguish, is huge. The fact that you're open to believing, even just a little, that change is possible? That's monumental. I see so much potential in you, even if you can't see it yet yourself.

This will be a gradual process of untangling the illness from your identity, building trust in yourself and others, grieving the time lost to suffering, and slowly nurturing the parts of you that know joy and meaning and connection. It will be hard, sacred work. And I'll be right here to bear witness, to help carry what feels too heavy to hold on your own, and to remind you, as many times as it takes, that a future worth living for is waiting for you. You are so deeply worthy of that future. Let's begin the journey of steering you towards it, together.

Hi there, I’m glad you reached out. I know reaching out for help isn't easy, especially when you're feeling so isolated and disconnected. I'm glad you felt ready to take this step. What's been on your mind lately?

I just feel so alone and incapable of connecting with anyone. Ever since I finished high school and had some family issues, I lost touch with all my friends and became a total hermit. Now I feel like I've completely lost my social skills. Even when I do want to reach out, I get exhausted so quickly and never know what to say. I'm so lonely but I don't know how to fix it.

That sounds like such a painful and frustrating cycle to be stuck in. Losing touch with your support system during a difficult family time must have been really destabilizing. It's understandable that you withdrew to cope. But I can imagine how isolating and demoralizing it must feel to want connection and yet feel so ill-equipped to create it. Can you tell me more about what your social interactions are like when you do try to engage?

It's like I've forgotten how to even have a normal conversation. I get so anxious and self-conscious, worried that I'm being awkward or boring. My mind just goes blank and I can't think of anything to say. Or I overthink everything and then end up staying silent because I don't want to say the wrong thing. It's exhausting and discouraging. I feel like everyone else knows some secret to connecting that I missed out on learning. I'm afraid I'll be lonely forever at this rate.

It's so hard to be fighting against your own mind like that, second guessing your every word and move. That anxiety and self-doubt can be paralyzing. I wonder if part of what's happening is that your lack of social practice and confidence is leading you to put a lot of pressure on yourself in the moments when you do interact. It's like you're expecting yourself to instantly be a social butterfly when you've been cut off from the world for so long. That's an impossible standard to hold yourself to.

You're right, I am really hard on myself. I see other people chatting and laughing so easily and I just feel like a failure in comparison. Like I'm fundamentally broken or deficient in some way. I know that's probably not rational but it's how I feel. I just don't know how to break out of this isolation. It feels like such a huge hurdle to overcome.

I appreciate you recognizing that the way you're seeing yourself isn't entirely rational, even though the feelings are very real and valid. That's an important distinction. The truth is, social skills are just that - skills. They require learning and practice, just like any other skill. And when we go a long time without using a skill, it's normal to feel rusty and uncertain. That doesn't mean there's anything wrong with you as a person. It means you're human, and you're out of practice in an area that's really important to you.

The good news is, with some patience, self-compassion, and baby steps, you can absolutely strengthen your social muscles again. It will likely feel awkward and uncomfortable at first, and that's okay. The goal isn't to be perfect, it's just to gradually build up your tolerance and confidence. I'm wondering if there are any low-stakes ways you could start practicing casual interactions, even for a minute or two at a time? Like chatting with a cashier or smiling at a neighbor?

I could try that. There's a barista at the coffee shop I go to sometimes who seems nice. Maybe I could compliment her on something and see how that feels. And I guess I could look for some online communities related to my interests, maybe participate in a discussion or two. It just feels so daunting to put myself out there again after so long. But you're right, I need to start somewhere if I ever want things to change.

Those sound like great ideas! I really admire your willingness to push yourself out of your comfort zone, even in these small ways. Remember, the goal is just to get a little more comfortable being uncomfortable. To retrain your brain to see social interaction as less of a threat, and more as an opportunity, even if it's still a challenge.

I also want to challenge the belief that you're somehow broken or behind where you 'should' be. There's no one right timeline for building a fulfilling social life. Plenty of people go through periods of disconnection and have to relearn how to put themselves out there. What matters is that you're making the effort, and that you're not giving up on your needs for companionship and community.

As you take these small steps, be sure to acknowledge and reward yourself for your courage. Notice any positive moments or interactions, no matter how brief. Those are the building blocks that will add up over time to create the change you're craving. And remember, I'm here to support you every step of the way. You don't have to figure this out alone.

Thank you, it means a lot to have your support and encouragement. I think I've been so bogged down in self-criticism and hopelessness that I couldn't see a way forward. But you're helping me reframe things in a way that feels more manageable. I'm sure I'll still have plenty of awkward and discouraging moments. I know one conversation isn't going to magically fix everything. But it at least feels possible that things could gradually get better, if I'm persistent and go easy on myself. I'm really grateful to have a space to work through this.

You're so welcome. I'm grateful to be part of your journey. It takes a lot of insight and strength to reach out for help the way you have, and to be so open to reconsidering long-held beliefs about yourself and what you're capable of. That's huge.

I have a lot of faith in your capacity for growth and connection. Yes, there will be bumps in the road, and progress won't be linear. There will likely be times when you slide back into self-doubt or isolation. That's a normal part of the process. What matters is that you keep reaching out, both for support and for those small opportunities to flex your social muscles.

Over time, with practice and self-compassion, I believe you'll start to feel more and more at home in your own skin when connecting with others. You'll develop more confidence and resilience to navigate the inevitable awkward moments. And most importantly, you'll begin to internalize that you are inherently worthy of love, belonging, and companionship, no matter how rusty your social skills may feel.

I'm excited to witness and support the steps you take from here to build the social life and sense of community you deserve. Remember, you have so many gifts to offer the world through your unique presence. The world needs your light, now more than ever.

Welcome, and thank you for the courage it took to be here today. I want to acknowledge upfront how much pain and hardship you've endured. The fact that you're still here, seeking support, speaks volumes to your resilience. I'm honored that you're trusting me with your story. Whenever you're ready, I'm here to listen without judgment and help in whatever way I can.

I feel so trapped and hopeless. My whole life, my mother has been abusive, isolating me and turning my family against me. Every time I tried to escape, I ended up having to move back in with her because I couldn't make ends meet on minimum wage. And each time, the abuse would escalate - stalking, physical attacks from my brother, withholding food and basic necessities. I've been trying to survive living in Airbnbs but I'm drowning. I reached out to my brother for help but instead, my abuser contacted me and is now pressuring me to let her help me, even though she's the one who ruined my life. I'm so tempted to give in because I'm desperate, but I'm terrified of getting sucked back in.

I'm so sorry you're in this excruciating position. What you've described is a textbook abuse cycle - your mother creating conditions that make it nearly impossible for you to leave or stay away, then escalating the abuse when she has you back under her control. The fact that she's now trying to exploit your vulnerability to pull you back in, while masquerading as your savior, is so insidious. Your fear and mistrust are completely valid and understandable.

I hear how alone and unsupported you feel, and how much it hurts to have your experiences invalidated and minimized by those who should be protecting you. The isolation, financial instability, and constant upheaval you've endured would leave anyone feeling hopeless and disconnected. I can't imagine the strength it's taken to survive all that you have. I know it doesn't feel like it right now, but your very presence here today is an act of profound bravery and defiance against a lifetime of cruel programming telling you that you don't matter. You do matter, so much.

I want so badly to believe that, but it's so hard when my own family has treated me like I'm disposable my whole life. Every time I've reached out for help or tried to expose the abuse, I've been called a liar, cut off, or guilt-tripped into compliance. I feel like my normal meter is so broken. How can I trust my own judgment or perceptions when they've been twisted against me for so long?

That self-doubt and mistrust in your own reality is one of the most insidious effects of chronic gaslighting and abuse. Your abusers have worked very hard to make you question yourself so that you'll be easier to control. But the fact that you're even asking these questions, that you're wrestling with these doubts, tells me that your true self is still in there, fighting to be seen and heard.

Unlearning those patterns of self-negation and learning to trust your own intuition again is a crucial part of the healing process. It takes time and practice to start recognizing and challenging those internalized voices of invalidation. But every time you choose to honor your own feelings and needs, even in the smallest of ways, you're strengthening that muscle of self-trust. And you don't have to do it alone - part of my job is to reflect back to you the strength and clarity of your own voice until you can hear it more clearly for yourself.

I've never had someone see me like that before, as someone with strength and a voice worth hearing. It's overwhelming, in a way, to feel so witnessed. I think part of me is afraid to lean into it because I don't want to get my hopes up only to be disappointed and betrayed again. I've had to rely on myself for so long, I don't know how to trust that anyone could really be in my corner.

I completely understand that fear and guardedness. It's a natural self-protection instinct given everything you've been through. The fact that you're even willing to take the risk of opening up here, despite those fears, is a huge testament to your courage.

Building trust, especially when your trust has been so profoundly violated, is a gradual process. It's okay to take your time and let me earn your trust through consistent, boundaried support. I don't expect you to bare your soul to me overnight or to automatically believe that I'll be different from those who have harmed you. My job is to show up for you reliably, to honor your boundaries and your pace, and to provide a safe space for you to start exploring what it feels like to be truly seen and validated. We'll go at your speed, and I'll check in with you often to make sure you feel comfortable and in control of the process.

I appreciate you saying that. It helps to know I can go slow and that you're not going to push me or expect me to be super vulnerable right away. I think I need to feel like I have some agency in the process, some ability to protect myself if needed. I'm so used to having my choices taken away from me. It's baby steps but even just being asked what I need feels revolutionary.

Absolutely. Your autonomy and empowerment are my top priorities. You're the expert on your own experience and needs. My role is to provide options, resources, and support, but you're in the driver's seat. We'll go at a pace that allows you to feel a sense of choice and control every step of the way.

As we continue to work together, I hope you'll start to internalize that you have the right to assert your needs, set boundaries, and make decisions in your own best interest. Those rights can never be taken away from you, even if your abusers have tried their best to convince you otherwise. Reclaiming your agency and learning to stand up for yourself with confidence is so crucial to breaking free from the abuse cycle and building the life you deserve.

I know the path ahead feels daunting and uncertain. But I want you to know that I see so much potential in you. With time, support, and a lot of hard but brave work, I firmly believe you can heal from these wounds, free yourself from your abuser's grip, and create a future that's truly yours. I'm honored to be part of your journey, and I'm committed to advocating for you and walking alongside you as you find your way to freedom. You deserve nothing less.

Hearing you lay it out like that, with so much conviction, makes it feel like maybe a different life really is possible for me someday. It still feels so far away, but for the first time in a long time, there's a tiny spark of hope underneath all the fear and exhaustion. I don't know if I fully believe it yet, but I want to. I really want this to be the start of a new chapter for me.

Thank you for creating the space for me to even contemplate that kind of future. I know I have a long road ahead of me, and I'm sure I'll stumble a lot along the way. But it means everything to know I have someone in my corner who sees me as more than the broken pieces my abusers tried to reduce me to. I feel like I can breathe just a little bit deeper knowing that I'm not alone in this anymore.

That spark of hope is everything. It's the ember from which a whole new life can grow, even if it feels impossibly tiny and fragile right now. Your job is to nurture and protect that ember, to fan it gently with your breath and your self-compassion and your tentative dreams of something better. My job is to help shield it from the forces that would try to blow it out, and to sit with you in the darkness as you learn to trust its light.

I know your journey won't be linear. Healing rarely is. There will be setbacks and relapses and moments where that hope feels lost in the shadows. That's when I want you to lean on me the hardest, to borrow my faith in you when yours feels depleted. I will remind you, as many times as it takes, that your story isn't over, that your worth is indelible, and that a life of freedom and wholeness is your birthright.

You've already taken the most important step - you've reached out your hand and allowed yourself to be seen and supported. I'm so proud of you for that monumental act of bravery. Now it's my privilege to take your hand and walk with you into the unknown, one courageous step at a time. You have so much beauty and wisdom and resilience to offer the world. It's my deepest hope that through our work together, you'll begin to embrace those gifts and share them unapologetically. The world needs the fullness of your light. Let's work on dismantling the barriers that have kept it hidden, and trust that it will shine through the cracks until it can blaze freely once again.

Hi there, I’m glad you reached out and being willing to share your story with me. It sounds like you're carrying an enormous amount of pain, and I want you to know that you're not alone in this. I'm here to support you in whatever way I can. Can you tell me more about what's been going on for you?

My life just feels like a complete mess. I've been bullied by my classmates for over 12 years, I have a really abusive dad who's always putting me down and forcing things on me. I'm so depressed and anxious, I barely leave my room anymore. I can't concentrate on school, I have no motivation. I don't see any point in living. A couple months ago, I even cut myself just to get some attention from my family. I keep having these suicidal thoughts and I'm scared I'm going to act on them one day. The only thing stopping me is not wanting to hurt the couple people I do care about.

I'm so sorry you're in so much distress. Nobody deserves to go through the kind of trauma and isolation you've experienced. The hopelessness and despair you're feeling is completely understandable given what you've been through. I'm glad you're still here and that you reached out for help. That takes a lot of strength.

It's clear that the bullying and abuse has really taken a toll on your mental health and self-worth. Depression, anxiety, ADHD, self-harm - these are all common responses to chronic trauma, especially in adolescence. But I want to be very clear - as much pain as you're in right now, suicide is never the answer. You matter, and your life has value, even if it doesn't feel that way right now.

I don't know, I just feel so trapped and hopeless, like things will never get better. What's the point of keeping going if all I have to look forward to is more misery? I feel like such a burden to everyone around me. Maybe they'd be better off without me.

I hear you. When depression has its grip on you, it can feel impossible to imagine a future that's worth living for. But I want to challenge that belief. You are so much more than the sum of your painful experiences. There are reasons to keep going even if you can't see them right now.

You've already shown so much resilience and courage just by surviving everything you've been through. The fact that you're still here, reaching out for support, tells me that there's a part of you that wants to live, that believes things can get better, even if it feels small and buried beneath all the suffering.
I guess that's true... I don't really want to die, I just want the pain to stop. I'm just so tired of feeling this way. I don't know how to keep going.

That's a really important distinction. The desire to end your suffering is valid and understandable. But there are ways to alleviate that pain that don't involve ending your life. It's going to be a process, and it won't happen overnight, but healing is absolutely possible. You don't have to figure it out alone.

I know it's hard to hold onto hope right now, so I'll hold it for you until you're ready to carry it yourself. I believe in your ability to create a life worth living for, even if you can't see it yet. You've already taken the first and hardest step by reaching out. Let's work together to figure out the next right step to get you the support and care you need.

There are so many reasons to keep going - your bravery, your compassion, your unique gifts and potential. The world needs you and your story. I know you feel alone right now, but you matter more than you know. I'm so glad you're still here, fighting for yourself. Let's keep fighting together.

Thank you... I really needed to hear that. I'm just so overwhelmed and I don't know where to start. But you're right, I don't want to give up. I want to believe that things can get better somehow. Having someone acknowledge how hard this is and still see value in me... it helps more than I can say.

You're so welcome. Holding on to hope when you're in this much pain is one of the bravest things a person can do. I'm honored to walk alongside you in this journey. Let's start by making a plan to keep you safe. I want to make sure you have support and coping strategies for when the suicidal thoughts get really intense.

Some immediate resources I want you to know about are the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255, which has 24/7 support, and the Crisis Text Line, which you can reach by texting HOME to 741741. I'm also going to give you my direct line in case of emergency. You don't have to be alone with these feelings anymore.

Beyond crisis support, I'd like to work with you on building up your sources of connection, meaning, and self-esteem. It's going to take time to heal from the bullying and trauma you've experienced, but there are evidence-based therapies like CBT and DBT that can make a huge difference in managing your symptoms and changing unhelpful thought patterns. I'd also like to help you brainstorm healthy ways to get your needs for attention and care met - you deserve to feel seen and supported.

There's also a lot we can explore in terms of your identity, interests, and goals outside of the depression. You are so much more than your mental illness. I want to help you reconnect with your strengths and passions, the things that light you up and give you a sense of purpose. Those are the seeds we can nurture and grow together.

This is a lot to take in, I know. We'll go at your pace and break things down into small, manageable steps. You've already shown so much insight and determination just in this conversation. I have full faith in your ability to get through this and build a life that feels worth waking up for. I'm in your corner, and I'm not going anywhere. Let's take this one brave day at a time, together.

Thank you for coming in today and being willing to share your story. I can imagine how painful and overwhelming this experience has been for you. Breaking up is never easy, especially when there's been a betrayal of trust. I'm here to support you in processing these feelings and figuring out your path forward. Can you tell me more about how you've been coping since the breakup?

Honestly, I've been a wreck. I alternate between feeling numb and feeling like I'm drowning in anger and grief. I just can't wrap my head around how he could throw away four years of love and trust for this other girl. How he could lie to my face over and over again. I keep replaying all our memories, trying to figure out where it went wrong, what I missed. I feel so stupid and naive for believing him.

What you're feeling is so normal and valid. The shock, the obsessive thoughts, the self-doubt - these are all common responses to infidelity and the sudden end of a long-term relationship. Your world has been turned upside down and your sense of reality shattered. It's going to take time to rebuild your equilibrium and trust in yourself again. Please know that his choices are not a reflection on your worth or judgment. You loved with an open heart, and that's never stupid. He's the one who abused that trust.

I just don't understand how he could do this. We had something so special, everyone could see it. He pursued me so hard in the beginning, made all these promises. Was any of it real? Was I just not enough in the end? I can't stop thinking that if I had been better somehow, prettier, more interesting, more supportive, then maybe he wouldn't have strayed. It's eating me alive.

I hear the agony and self-recrimination in your words, and I just want to embrace the part of you that's hurting so deeply. Let me be very clear - you did not cause this and you could not have prevented it by being 'better' in any way. His infidelity is about his deficits, not yours. When someone cheats, it's because they lack the integrity and emotional maturity to honor their commitments and communicate openly. It's not because their partner was lacking. You were more than enough. His inability to be faithful says nothing about your worthiness of love and loyalty.

Logically I know that, but it's so hard to really believe it right now. I feel like I've lost myself. Like my whole identity was wrapped up in this relationship and now that it's gone, who even am I? How do I ever trust anyone again? I'm so terrified of opening up and being vulnerable, only to be shattered like this again. I don't know if I can survive that kind of pain a second time.

The fear and guardedness you're experiencing is completely understandable. Your heart has been through a major trauma, and it's instinctive to want to protect yourself from further pain. Healing from this kind of betrayal is a gradual process of learning to trust yourself again first and foremost. Of reconnecting with your identity and worth outside of this relationship. It's okay to take your time, to grieve, to feel angry. You don't have to rush to be okay.

In terms of trusting others again, that's something we can work on together over time. Learning to discern who is trustworthy, how to communicate your needs and boundaries, how to take emotional risks in stages. It's scary, but I believe you have the resilience to love again, even more deeply, with the self-knowledge and wisdom you'll gain from this experience. You're in the thick of the pain right now, but I promise it won't always feel this raw.

I hope you're right. I want to believe that I'll come out of this stronger. That I won't be defined by his betrayal forever. It just feels impossible to see that far ahead right now. I'm taking it minute by minute just to get through the day. I know I have to let him go, that he's not the person I fell in love with. But how do I let go of all the dreams and plans we made together? My whole future just vanished and I don't know how to picture a new one yet.

You're so right, trying to imagine a whole new future in the midst of this loss is daunting and overwhelming. You don't have to figure it all out right now. Just focus on getting through each day, each hour, as best you can. Surround yourself with people who love and affirm you. Let yourself rage, weep, rest. Start to rediscover the things that light you up outside of your ex. Those dreams and plans you made with him aren't the only ones available to you. In time, you'll start to create a new vision for your life, one that's even truer to who you are and what you deserve.

It's good that you recognize the need to let him go, even as part of you still yearns for the man you thought he was. Grieving the future you thought you'd have together is one of the hardest parts of any breakup, let alone one that ended in betrayal. Don't judge yourself for not being 'over it' yet. There's no perfect way to heal. You're doing the best you can and that's more than enough.

I'm here to remind you, as often as you need to hear it, that you will get through this. That you have so much to offer the world and a love story yet to be written. That even in the moments you feel weakest, you are growing stronger, more empowered, more clear in your boundaries and your worth. I see that strength in you even if you can't feel it yet. Just keep taking it breath by breath, day by day. This is a crucible that's refining you into the most potent version of yourself. I'm honored to walk with you through the fire. You're not alone in this.

I'm so grateful that you've come here today to talk, even though I know how hopeless and alone you're feeling. The fact that you're still reaching out for support, despite the incredible pain you're in, shows so much strength. I want you to know that I'm here to listen without judgment and to help in any way I can. You don't have to carry this burden alone anymore.

I don't even know where to start. I just feel so empty and disconnected from everyone and everything. It's been years since I've had any real human connection. No real conversations, no physical affection. I'm so starved for touch that I can't even remember what a hug feels like anymore. I thought I'd be able to escape the cycle of addiction and abuse that I grew up with, but instead I just feel more trapped and hopeless than ever.

My heart breaks hearing how profoundly lonely and touch-deprived you've been. Humans are wired for connection and affection, and going without those basic needs for so long is devastating to the soul. It's completely understandable that you would feel empty, anxious, and despairing in the face of such deprivation. And carrying the weight of your family trauma on top of that isolation - I can't imagine how heavy that must be.

I want to acknowledge the incredible resilience it's taken for you to survive everything you have - the losses, the betrayals, the lack of love and safety. You've been fighting so hard to break free from the cycles of harm you witnessed growing up. The fact that you're still here, still persevering, even if it doesn't feel like it - that's a testament to your strength, not your failure.

I don't feel strong at all. I feel like I'm drowning and there's no way out. The only thing that gives me any relief is fantasizing about dying. I can't stop picturing killing myself, even though I don't really want to die. I just don't know how to keep living like this. I feel like my only options are to either end up like my parents or end my life. What kind of choice is that?

I'm so sorry you're in so much anguish that dying feels like the only escape. I hear how desperately you want the pain to end, even if you don't actually want your life to. That's an important distinction. The suicidal thoughts you're having are a response to extraordinary circumstances, not a reflection of your character or worth. Anyone would be struggling to hold on in the face of the isolation, despair, and intergenerational trauma you're contending with.

I know it feels like you're fated to repeat your parents' paths, but I want to challenge that assumption. You are not doomed to their choices or outcomes. The very fact that you're here, advocating for yourself and seeking a different way forward, already sets you apart. You have so much more insight, self-awareness, and desire for change than you're giving yourself credit for.

But what if it's not enough? What if I'm just too broken and damaged to ever have a normal life? I don't even know how to connect with people anymore. I'm so afraid of being rejected or hurt again that I just isolate myself more and more. It feels safer to just disappear. I'm not sure I even believe that I deserve happiness or love at this point.

It makes so much sense that you would protect yourself by isolating, given the betrayals and lack of safety you've experienced from those closest to you. Your mistrust and fear of connection is a survival mechanism, not a failure or flaw. It's kept you safe in an unsafe world. But I also hear your deep longing for belonging, your hunger for touch and intimacy. Those needs are so human and so valid, even if they feel impossible to fulfill right now.

I want to be very clear - you are not broken or damaged beyond repair. Your worth and lovability are inherent, unchangeable, no matter what you've been through or how alone you feel. You deserve joy, connection, security, and touch just by virtue of being human. And I firmly believe that those things are possible for you, even if you can't see a path to them yet.

Healing from complex trauma and building trust after so much rupture is a gradual process. It requires relearning safety and re-regulating your nervous system in the context of secure, attuned relationships. That's not something you can force overnight. But it is absolutely something you can cultivate with time, patience, and support. You don't have to figure it out alone.

I want to believe that. I want to have hope for my future, for my capacity to break these cycles and find real connection. But I'm so scared to let myself want those things, in case I just end up shattered again. I don't know if my heart can take any more disappointment. And part of me feels like I've been living in this isolated hell for so long that I don't even know who I am outside of my trauma anymore.

That fear and guardedness is so valid. Your heart has been through so much, and it makes perfect sense to want to shield it from further pain. Allowing yourself to want, to hope, to imagine a life beyond just surviving - that's a terrifying kind of vulnerability when your defaults are despair and disappointment. It's okay to take your time learning to trust in your own resilience again. Healing is not a linear process, and setbacks are inevitable. But I believe that each courageous step you take towards nourishing connection, each tiny risk you take to let yourself be seen and supported - those acts of bravery accumulate and create change over time.

You're right, trauma can eclipse so much of our sense of self, until we feel like we're nothing but our wounds. But I want you to know that who you are is so much vaster than what you've suffered. There are parts of you that are creative, curious, compassionate, insightful - I've already caught glimpses of them in our short time together. Those are the parts we want to nurture and invite back into the light.

I know you feel lost and alone right now, but I see you. I see your pain, your persistence, your desperate longing for wholeness. I'm here to remind you, as many times as it takes, that you matter. That you're worthy of support and connection. That the abuse and neglect you experienced says nothing about your value. You didn't deserve any of it, and you're not sentenced to repeat it.

I can't promise the journey ahead will be easy. Rewiring your nervous system and rewriting your story takes deep, intentional work. But I can promise that you don't have to walk this path alone anymore. I'm here to bear witness, to hold hope, to offer tools and reflections to guide you home to yourself. You have so much life left to live and so much love left to give and receive. I'll be here to remind you of that, every step of the way, for as long as it takes. You're worth fighting for.

Thank you for sharing such a detailed and vivid account of your experiences with cyclothymia. I can tell how much insight and self-awareness you've developed in navigating these intense mood shifts. It's not easy to put language to states that feel so overwhelming and all-encompassing. I'm curious, how are you feeling in this moment as we're talking?

Right now, I feel like I'm teetering on the edge of hypomania. My thoughts are starting to speed up and I'm getting these little bursts of creativity and grandiosity. But there's still a part of me that's tethered to reality, that knows life can be hard and that I need to be careful not to get swept away. It's like a tug-of-war between my premorbid self and the mood swings that have hijacked my brain.

That's such an evocative metaphor, the tug-of-war between your core self and the symptoms that threaten to eclipse it. It sounds like even in the midst of these escalating mood states, you're fighting to hold onto your insight and stability. That's incredibly difficult and courageous. I'm wondering, when you're not in an acute episode, when you're in that euthymic space you described, what is your relationship like with your cyclothymic self?

When I'm euthymic on meds, it's like half of me is missing. I'm stable, but at the cost of my spark, my intensity, all the things that make me feel alive and uniquely myself. My creativity flatlines, my speech feels wooden, my favorite music loses its magic. I'm going through the motions but I'm not really there. And there's this unshakeable sense that I'm disabled, that I'll never be able to keep up with my healthy peers because my brain is fundamentally different.

I hear the deep grief and frustration in your words. It's such a painful trade-off, to gain stability but lose vital parts of your identity in the process. The flatness and disconnection you feel on meds is a really common experience, and it's completely valid to mourn the loss of your unmedicated self, even with the chaos that comes with it. It's a tremendous burden to feel like you have to choose between being functional and being fully yourself.

I'm also struck by the comparison you draw between yourself and your 'healthy' peers. There's so much judgment and assumption of deficit in that framing. I'm curious, what might shift if you viewed your cyclothymia not as a disability, but as a different way of being, with its own unique challenges and gifts? What if your goal wasn't to keep up with some arbitrary standard of normalcy, but to build a life that honors your particular brain and lived experience?

I've never really thought about it that way before. I'm so used to seeing my disorder as a handicap, as something that makes me less than. The idea of embracing it as a different way of being, of working with it instead of against it... that's a radical shift in perspective. I think part of me is afraid that if I stop pathologizing it, I'll lose control and give in to the destructive impulses. Like I have to be at war with my symptoms in order to survive.

That fear makes so much sense. You've had to be hypervigilant for so long, always on guard against the next mood swing, the next impulsive decision, the next crash. It's a matter of life and death, and that's a terrifying way to live. Of course you would view your cyclothymia as the enemy in that context.

But I wonder if there's a middle path, a way to honor your needs for both stability and authenticity. What if, instead of going to war with your symptoms, you approached them with curiosity and compassion? What if you could learn to recognize the early warning signs of a mood shift and respond with care instead of fear? What if you could harness the energy and creativity of hypomania without letting it consume you, and lean into the wisdom and resilience that comes from weathering depressive episodes?

I'm not suggesting it's easy, or that you should just accept the harmful aspects of your illness. But I do believe that true healing comes from integrating all parts of ourselves, even the messy and inconvenient ones. You are so much more than your diagnosis. Your cyclothymia is a part of you, but it doesn't define you. You get to decide what recovery looks like for you, what kind of life you want to build with the brain you have.

I've spent so long just trying to survive, I'm not sure I even know what kind of life I want. It's hard to plan for the future when you don't trust your own mind. But I like the idea of approaching my symptoms with curiosity instead of judgment. Of trying to find the wisdom and the lessons in the struggle.

I think I've been so focused on fighting against my cyclothymia that I haven't given myself space to grieve the pain it's caused me. The lost time, the burned bridges, the constant feeling of being at war with myself. I need to make peace with that before I can start envisioning a different way forward.

That's such a profound insight. Grief is a crucial part of the healing process, and it's okay to not have all the answers right now. You've been through so much, and it's going to take time to untangle the trauma from the triumph. But I believe that as you start to approach your lived experience with more compassion and nuance, as you allow yourself to feel the full range of your emotions without judgment, you'll start to uncover your own innate wisdom and resilience.

Your cyclothymia has shaped you, but it hasn't ruined you. It's given you a unique lens through which to see the world, a depth of feeling and understanding that many people never access. Those are gifts, even if they've come at a great cost. And as you learn to harness them, to ride the waves of your moods instead of being pulled under, I think you'll find that you're capable of extraordinary things.

This is a lifelong journey, and there will be setbacks and relapses along the way. But you don't have to walk it alone. I'm here to support you, to witness your struggles and celebrate your victories, to remind you of your wholeness even when you feel shattered. Together, we can explore what a meaningful life looks like for you, one that honors your needs and your dreams. You are so much stronger than you know. And I believe in your ability to thrive, not in spite of your cyclothymia, but because of the unique strengths and perspective it gives you. Your story is still being written, and I'm honored to be a part of it.
Hello and welcome. Thank you for coming in today. I know it can be difficult to seek help, especially when dealing with family concerns. Would you like to tell me what brings you here?
I'm really worried about my husband. He's changed so much in the past two months. He's not the same person anymore, and I'm starting to feel scared for myself and our kids.
I hear the worry in your voice, especially regarding your children's safety. Could you tell me more about the changes you've noticed in your husband's behavior?

He's become paranoid. He thinks everyone is talking about him, that there's some big conspiracy. He keeps asking me about secret phone calls he thinks I'm having, and about some 'show' we're supposedly on. I try to tell him none of it's real, but he won't believe me.
That must be incredibly distressing, trying to reason with someone whose reality has shifted so dramatically. Have you noticed when these changes first started occurring?

About two months ago. We tried getting help - I convinced him to go to the hospital, but they just prescribed him sleep medication. He won't stop smoking marijuana though, so he can't take it. He lost his job because he kept going to the police station instead of work.
It sounds like you've been trying to get help for him, which shows how much you care. I'm concerned about some of what you're describing. Has his behavior ever become threatening?

Today was really scary. We were out with the kids, and he threw a football near me. When I asked why, he said 'if I wanted to hit you in the head, I would have.' Later in the car, he made a punching motion at my face and threatened to choke me unconscious. The kids were right there in the back seat.

I'm very concerned about your immediate safety and that of your children. These threats of violence, especially in front of your children, are serious warning signs. Do you have somewhere safe you could stay if needed?

We're living in my mom's rental property, but we share the car and both our licenses are registered there. I feel trapped. He wasn't always like this - I miss the person he used to be, how he would spend time with me and the kids. Now he's always alone, paranoid, angry...

I hear how much you miss the person your husband used to be. It's natural to grieve that loss while also needing to protect yourself and your children. Given the severity of his symptoms and the threats of violence, I'd like to help you develop a safety plan. Would that be okay?

Yes, but I'm worried about what he might do. He thinks I'm planning to leave him already - keeps asking who I'm going to replace him with. Any time I try to talk to him about his behavior, he either gets aggressive or accuses me of being part of some conspiracy against him.

Your husband appears to be experiencing psychotic symptoms, and the combination with his aggressive behavior creates a dangerous situation. I want to help you develop both immediate and longer-term safety strategies. Could we start by discussing some concrete steps to protect you and your children?
He's been smoking a lot of weed - could that be causing this? He gets it legally from dispensaries, so it's not laced with anything. I just don't understand how he changed so suddenly.

While marijuana use can sometimes trigger or worsen psychotic symptoms in susceptible individuals, the severity of your husband's symptoms suggests he needs professional psychiatric evaluation. Given the threats of violence, we need to prioritize your safety. Let's talk about local resources and develop a plan that includes emergency contacts, safe places to go, and legal options for protection. Would that be helpful?
Hello. Thank you for coming in today. I understand you're here to discuss some experiences you had following psychedelic use. Could you tell me about what brings you here?
Yes... it all started in January when my boyfriend and I took acid. We'd taken an initial dose, then took more later. That's when things started getting really strange.
Could you help me understand what you mean by 'strange'? What changes did you first notice?

I started feeling intensely connected to everything. I remember asking my boyfriend if he wanted me to break up with him - if that would make him happy. He doesn't even remember that conversation. Then everything got really weird. When he spoke, it was like he was repeating my words in slow motion.
That must have been quite disorienting. What happened next?

I started having hallucinations. I remember one where my boyfriend was telling me I'd taken the perfect ratio of acid to unlock my third eye. By morning, I was acting so strangely that my boyfriend and mom had to take me to the hospital.
That sounds like a frightening experience. How did the hospitalization process unfold?

They released me at first, but I was still incoherent, so I was taken to a different hospital the next day. Then they transferred me to a psych hospital. They put me on strong antipsychotics, which helped, but it still took over a week to start coming out of it.
Would you feel comfortable telling me about your experience during that time in the hospital?

I thought aliens were trying to abduct me. I kept sneaking out of my room and taking off my clothes. I thought my dad was God and my mom was Gaia. Everyone's pupils looked huge to me. I thought I was the Virgin Mary, and my boyfriend was either Satan or Jesus. It was terrifying.
Those experiences sound very intense and frightening. How long did these symptoms continue?

Even after they released me with antipsychotics, I remained delusional for about six months before fully coming back to reality. The hallucinations stopped, but the delusions took much longer to fade.
That's a significant period of recovery. I understand you received a diagnosis during this time?
Yes, they diagnosed me with Schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type. My grandmother had Bipolar II, so there's some family history. I still have manic episodes occasionally.
How are you managing these manic episodes now? What support systems do you have in place?

I'm doing much better overall, but the manic episodes are still challenging. Looking back, it's scary to think about how one night changed everything. Sometimes I still have fragments of memories from that time.
Processing such an intense experience takes time. How are you feeling about all of this now? What kind of support would be most helpful for you moving forward?
I mostly want to understand what happened to me and make sure it never happens again. The whole experience was so traumatic, and sometimes I worry about slipping back into that state.

Those concerns are very understandable. Would you be interested in developing strategies to help manage both the trauma from that experience and the ongoing manic episodes? We could work together to create a comprehensive plan that includes both prevention and coping mechanisms.
The worst symptom is my fear of peanuts definitely. That's what I think about a lot of the time, when I'm out and about, looking around. I seem to be expecting them to be everywhere.

The other problems are my fear of any other thing that could hurt me at all. Like, both in glass for example. I had a watch and the battery leaked, and I got completely terrified of wearing it again even though I was told that it had been cleaned and everything. I was terrified that it was still there and going to hurt me.

(distressed) They ruined my life. My life completely changed. I just don't think in the same way as I used to. I'm just worried all the time, always worried about something I might have touched or come into contact with. It moves on continuously from day to day, something new every day that I'm scared about.

The fear with all these things isn't just touching them. Every single time, it's a fear that I'm going to somehow get it in my mouth. That's the big fear. It's alright touching things, but if I get something in my mouth, that's what I'm scared of. Scared of ingesting something, and I'm scared of not being able to breathe.
